direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gulf and Western Plaza March 29, 1971                                New York, New York 10019 INT DAY: DON'S OFFICE (SUMMER 1945) The PARAMOUNT Logo is presented austerely over a black background.  There is a moment's hesitation, and then the simple words in white lettering:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: While this remains, we hear: "I believe in America." Suddenly we are watching in CLOSE VIEW, AMERIGO BONASERA, a man of sixty, dressed in a black suit, on the verge of great emotion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: America has made my fortune. As he speaks, THE VIEW imperceptibly begins to loosen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I raised my daughter in the American fashion; I gave her freedom, but taught her never to dishonor her family.  She found a boy friend, not an Italian.  She went to the movies with him, stayed out late. Two months ago he took her for a drive, with another boy friend. They made her drink whiskey and then they tried to take advantage of her.  She resisted; she kept her honor.  So they beat her like an animal.  When I went to the hospital her nose was broken, her jaw was shattered and held together by wire, and she could not even weep because of the pain. He can barely speak; he is weeping now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I went to the Police like a good American.  These two boys were arrested and brought to trial.  The judge sentenced them to three years in prison, and suspended the sentence.  Suspended sentence! They went free that very day.  I stood in the courtroom like a fool, and those bastards, they smiled at me.  Then I said to my wife, for Justice, we must go to The Godfather. By now, THE VIEW is full, and we see Don Corleone's office in his home. The blinds are closed, and so the room is dark, and with patterned shadows.  We are watching BONASERA over the shoulder of DON CORLEONE.  TOM HAGEN sits near a small table, examining some paperwork, and SONNY CORLEONE stands impatiently by the window nearest his father, sipping from a glass of wine.  We can HEAR music, and the laughter and voices of many people outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bonasera, we know each other for years, but this is the first time you come to me for help.  I don't remember the last time you invited me to your house for coffee...even though our wives are friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you want of me?  I'll give you anything you want, but do what I ask!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what is that Bonasera?
direction.name: direction

result.heading: FRANCIS FORD COPPOLA THIRD DRAFT PARAMOUNT PICTURES 1

direction.raw_text: whispers into the DON's ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  You ask for too much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I ask for Justice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Court gave you justice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An eye for an eye!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But your daughter is still alive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then make them suffer as she suffers.  How much shall I pay you. Both HAGEN and SONNY react.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You never think to protect yourself with real friends.  You think it's enough to be an American.  All right, the Police protects you, there are Courts of Law, so you don't need a friend like me. But now you come to me and say Don Corleone, you must give me justice. And you don't ask in respect or friendship.  And you don't think to call me Godfather; instead you come to my house on the day my daughter is to be married and you ask me to do murder...for money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: America has been good to me...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then take the justice from the judge, the bitter with the sweet, Bonasera.  But if you come to me with your friendship, your loyalty, then your enemies become my enemies, and then, believe me, they would fear you... Slowly, Bonasera bows his head and murmurs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be my friend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good.  From me you'll get Justice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Godfather.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some day, and that day may never come, I would like to call upon you to do me a service in return.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MALL (SUMMER 1945) A HIGH ANGLE of the CORLEONE MALL in bright daylight.  There are at least five hundred guests filling the main courtyard and gardens.  There is music and laughing and dancing and countless tables covered with food and wine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stands at the Gate, flanked on either side by a son: FREDO and SONNY, all dressed in the formal attire of the wedding party.  He warmly shakes the hands, squeezes the hands of the friends and guests, pinches the cheeks of the children, and makes them all welcome.  They in turn carry with them gallons of homemade wine, cartons of freshly baked bread and pastries, and enormous trays of Italian delicacies. The entire family poses for a family portrait: DON CORLEONE, MAMA, SONNY, his wife, SANDRA, and their children, TOM HAGEN and his wife, THERESA, and their BABY; CONSTANZIA, the bride, and her bridegroom, CARLO RIZZI.  As they move into the pose, THE DON seems preoccupied.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's Michael?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'll be here Pop, it's still early.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then the picture will wait for him. Everyone in the group feels the uneasiness as the DON moves back to the house.  SONNY gives a delicious smile in the direction of the Maid-of-Honor, LUCY MANCINI.  She returns it.  Then he moves to his wife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sandra, watch the kids.  They're running wild.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You watch yourself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: kisses his WIFE, and follows THE DON, passing the wine barrels, where a group of FOUR MEN nervously wait.  TOM crooks a finger at NAZORINE, who doublechecks that he is next, straightens, and follows HAGEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MALL ENTRANCE (SUMMER 1945) Outside the main gate of the Mall, SEVERAL MEN in suits, working together with a MAN in a dark sedan, walk in and out of the rows of parked cars, writing license plate numbers down in their notebooks.  We HEAR the music and laughter coming from the party in the distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stops at a limousine and copies down the number.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: dignified in a black homburg, is always under the watchful eyes of TWO BODYGUARDS as he makes his way to embrace DON CORLEONE in the courtyard. The MEN walk down another row of parked cars.  Put another number in the notebook.  A shiney new Cadillac with wooden bumpers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: dancing the Tarantella joyously, bumping bellies with the ladies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paulie...wine...WINE. He mops his sweating forehead with a big handkerchief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: hustles, gets a glass of icy black wine, and brings it to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You look terrif on the floor!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you, a dance judge?  Go do your job; take a walk around the neighborhood... see everything is okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: nods and leaves; CLEMENZA takes a breath, and leaps back into the dance. The MEN walk down another row of parked cars.  Put another number in the notebook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a tall, gentle-looking man, dances with a NINE-YEAR- OLD GIRL, her little black party shoes planted on his enormous brown shoes. The MEN move on to other parked cars, when SONNY storms out of the gate, his face flushed with anger, followed by
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and PAULIE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Buddy, this is a private party. The MAN doesn't answer, but points to the DRIVER of the sedan.  SONNY menacingly thrusts his reddened face at him. The DRIVER merely flips open his wallet to a greed card, without saying a word.  SONNY steps back, spits on the ground, turns, and walks away, followed by CLEMENZA, PAULIE, and another TWO MEN.  He doesn't say a thing for most of the walk back into the courtyard, and then, muttered to PAULIE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goddamn FBI...don't respect nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S OFFICE (SUMMER 1945) DON CORLEONE sits quietly behind his massive desk in the dark study.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...a fine boy from Sicily, captured by the American Army, and sent to New Jersey as a prisoner of war...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nazorine, my friend, tell me what I can do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now that the war is over, Enzo, this boy is being repatriated to Italy.  And you see, Godfather... (he wrings his hands, unable to express himself) He...my daughter...they...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want him to stay in this country.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Godfather, you understand everything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom, what we need is an Act of Congress to allow Enzo to become a citizen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An Act of Congress!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It will cost. The DON shrugs; such are the way with those things; NAZORINE nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that all?  Godfather, thank you... (backing out, enthusiastically) Oh, wait till you see the cake I made for your beautiful daughter!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: backs out, all smiles, and nods to the GODFATHER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: rises and moves to the Venetian blinds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who do I give this job to? The DON moves to the windows, peeking out through the blinds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not to one of our paisans...give it to a Jew Congressman in another district.  Who else is on the list for today? The DON is peeking out to the MEN around the barrel, waiting to see him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Francesco Nippi.  His nephew has been refused parole.  A bad case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MALL (SUMMER 1945) WHAT HE SEES:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: waits nervously by the barrel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His father worked with you in the freight yards when you were young.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: sitting alone, grotesque and quiet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's not on the list, but Luca Brasi wants to see you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S OFFICE (SUMMER 1945) The DON turns to HAGEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is it necessary?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You understand him better than anyone. The DON nods to this.  Turns back to the blinds and peeks out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MALL (SUMMER 1945) WHAT HE SEES:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: dressed in the uniform of a Marine Captain, leads KAY ADAMS through the wedding crowd, occasionally stopped and greeted by FRIENDS of the family.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S OFFICE (SUMMER 1945) The DON, inside the office, peering through the blinds, following them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MALL (SUMMER 1945) MICHAEL moves through the crowd, embraces MAMA and introduces her to his GIRL.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : OFFICE WINDOW (SUMMER 1945) The DON's eyes peering through the blinds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MALL TABLES (SUMMER 1945) KAY and MICHAEL settle by a table on the edge of the wedding, burdened down with plates of food and glasses and wine.  She is exhilarated by the enormity of the affair, the music and the vitality.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've never seen anything like it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you I had a lot of relatives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looking about, a young and lively thing in a gift shop. We see what she sees: Her interest is caught by THREE MEN standing by the wine barrels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Michael, what are those men doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're waiting to see my father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're talking to themselves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're going to talk to my father, which means they're going to ask him for something, which means they better get it right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why do they bother him on a day like this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because they know that no Sicilian will refuse a request on his daughter's wedding day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : WEDDING PARTY (SUMMER 1945) CONNIE CORLEONE, the Bride, is pressing the bodice of her overly-fluffy white gown against the groom, CARLO RIZZI.  He is bronzed, with curly blondish hair and lovely dimples. She absolutely adores him and can barely take her eyes from him long enough to thank the various GUESTS for the white envelopes they are putting into the large white purse she holds.  In fact, if we watch carefully, we can see that one of her hands is slid under his jacket, and into his shirt, where she is provocatively rubbing the hair on his chest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on the other hand, has his blue eyes trained on the bulging envelopes, and is trying to guess how much cash the things hold. Discreetly, he moves her hand off of his skin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cut it out, Connie. The purse, looped by a ribbon of silk around CONNIE's arm, is fat with money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you think?  Twenty grand? A little distance away, a young man, PAULIE GATTO, catches a prosciutto sandwich thrown by a friend, without once taking eyes from the purse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who knows?  Maybe more.  Twenty, thirty grand in small bills cash in that silk purse.  Holy Toledo, if this was somebody else's wedding!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is sitting at the Wedding Dias, talking to LUCY MANCINI, the Maid of Honor.  Every once in a while he glances across the courtyard, where his WIFE is talking with some WOMEN. He bends over and whispers something into LUCY's ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and the WOMEN are in the middle of a big, ribald laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is it true what they say about your husband, Sandra? SANDRA's hands separate with expanding width further and further apart until she bursts into a peal of laughter. Through her separated hands she sees the Wedding Dais.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and LUCY are gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S HALL & STAIRS (SUMMER 1945) The empty hallway.  The bathroom door opens and LUCY surreptitiously steps out. She looks up where SONNY is standing on the second landing, motioning for her to come up. She lifts her petticoats off the ground and hurries upstairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MALL TABLES (SUMMER 1945) KAY and MICHAEL.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Michael, that scarey guy...Is he a relative? She has picked out LUCA BRASI.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  His name is Luca Brasi.  You wouldn't like him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You really want to know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.  Tell me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You like spaghetti?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know I love spaghetti.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then eat your spaghetti and I'll tell you a Luca Brasi story. She starts to eat her spaghetti. She begins eating, looking at him eagerly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Once upon a time, about fifteen years ago some people wanted to take over my father's olive oil business.  They had Al Capone send some men in from Chicago to kill my father, and they almost did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Al Capone!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My Father sent Luca Brasi after them.  He tied the two Capone men hand and foot, and stuffed small bath towels into their mouths. Then he took an ax, and chopped one man's feet off...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Michael...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then the legs at the knees...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Michael you're trying to scare me...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then the thighs where they joined the torso.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Michael, I don't want to hear anymore...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then Luca turned to the other man...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Michael, I love you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...who out of sheer terror had swallowed the bath towel in his mouth and suffocated. The smile on his face seems to indicate that he is telling a tall story.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never know when you're telling me the truth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you you wouldn't like him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's coming over here!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: comes toward them to meet TOM HAGEN halfway, just near their table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom...Tom, I'd like you to meet Kay Adams.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My brother, Tom Hagen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello Kay.  Your father's inside, doing some business. (privately) He's been asking for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks Tom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: smiles and moves back to the house, LUCA ominously following.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If he's your brother, why does he have a different name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My brother Sonny found him living in the streets when he was a kid, so my father took him in.  He's a good lawyer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S OFFICE (SUMMER 1945) DON CORLEONE at the window.  He has seen the intimacy of the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don Corleone...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: turns to the stiffly formal LUCA, and he moves forward to kiss his hand.  He takes the envelope from his jacket, holds it out, but does not release it until he makes a formal speech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don Corleone...I am honored, and grateful...that you invited me to your home...on the wedding day of your...daughter. May their first child...be a masculine child.  I pledge my never ending loyalty. (he offers the envelope) For your daughter's bridal purse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Luca, my most valued friend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: takes it, and then LUCA's hand, which he squeezes so tightly we might imagine it to be painful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me leave you, Don Corleone.  I know you are busy. He turns, almost an about-face, and leaves the study with the same formality he entered with.  DON CORLEONE breathes more easily, and gives the thick envelope to HAGEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure it's the most generous gift today.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Senator called--apologized for not coming personally, but said you'd understand.  Also, some of the Judges...they've all sent gifts. And another call from Virgil Sollozzo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is not pleased.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The action is narcotics.  Sollozzo has contacts in Turkey for the poppy, in Sicily for the plants to process down to morphine or up to heroin.  Also he has access to this country.  He's coming to us for financial help, and some sort of immunity from the law.  For that we get a piece of the action, I couldn't find out how much. Sollozzo is vouched for by the Tattaglia family, and they may have a piece of the action.  They call Sollozzo the Turk. He's spent a lot of time in Turkey and is suppose to have a Turkish wife and kids.  He's suppose to be very quick with the knife, or was, when he was younger.  Only in matters of business and with some reasonable complaint.  Also he has an American wife and three children and he is a good family man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's his own boss, and very competent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And with prison record.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two terms; one in Italy, one in the United States.  He's known to the Government as a top narcotics man. That could be a plus for us; he could never get immunity to testify.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When did he call?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On a day like this.  Consiglero, do you also have in your notes the the Turk made his living from Prostitution before the war, like the Tattaglias do now.  Write that down before you forget it.  The Turk will wait. We now begin to hear a song coming over the loud-speakers from outside.  In Italian, with unmistakable style.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What that?  It sounds like Johnny. He moves to the window, pulls the blinds up, flooding the room with light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is Johnny.  He came all the way from California to be at the wedding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Should I bring him in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  Let the people enjoy him.  You see?  He is a good godson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's been two years.  He's probably in trouble again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MALL (SUMMER 1945) JOHNNY FONTANE on the bandstand, singing to the delight and excitement of the wedding GUESTS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't know your family knew Johnny Fontane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I used to come down to New York whenever he sang at the Capitol and scream my head off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's my father's godson; he owes him his whole career.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: finishes the song and the CROWD screams with delight. They call out for another when DON CORLEONE appears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My Godson has come three thousand miles to do us honor and no one thinks to wet his throat. At once a dozen wine glasses are offered to JOHNNY, who takes a sip from each as he moves to embrace his GODFATHER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I kept trying to call you after my divorce and Tom always said you were busy.  When I got the Wedding invitation I knew you weren't sore at me anymore, Godfather.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I do something for you still? You're not too rich, or too famous that I can't help you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not rich anymore, Godfather, and...my career, I'm almost washed up... He's very disturbed.  The GODFATHER indicates that he come with him to the office so no one will notice.  He turns to
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell Santino to come in with us. He should hear some things. They go, leaving HAGEN scanning the party looking for SONNY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S OFFICE (SUMMER 1945) HAGEN glances up the staircase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sonny? Then he goes up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S UPSTAIRS ROOM (SUMMER 1945) SONNY and LUCY are in a room upstairs; he has lifted her gown's skirts almost over her head, and has her standing against the door.  Her face peeks out from the layers of petticoats around it like a flower in ecstasy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sonnyeeeeeeee. Her head bouncing against the door with the rhythm of his body.  But there is a knocking as well.  They stop, freeze in that position.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sonny?  Sonny, you in there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S UPSTAIRS HALLWAY (SUMMER 1945) Outside, HAGEN by the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The old man wants you; Johnny's here...he's got a problem.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.  One minute.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: hesitates.  We HEAR LUCY's head bouncing against the door again.  TOM leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S OFFICE (SUMMER 1945) DON CORLEONE ACT LIKE A MAN!  By Christ in Heaven, is it possible you turned out no better than a Hollywood finocchio. Both HAGEN and JOHNNY cannot refrain from laughing.  The DON smiles.  SONNY enters as noiselessly as possible, still adjusting his clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, Hollywood...Now tell me about this Hollywood Pezzonovanta who won't let you work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He owns the studio.  Just a month ago he bought the movie rights to this book, a best seller.  And the main character is a guy just like me.  I wouldn't even have to act, just be myself. The DON is silent, stern.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You take care of your family?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. He glances at SONNY, who makes himself as inconspicuous as he can.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You look terrible.  I want you to eat well, to rest.  And spend time with your family.  And then, at the end of the month, this big shot will give you the part you want.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's too late.  All the contracts have been signed, they're almost ready to shoot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll make him an offer he can't refuse. He takes JOHNNY to the door, pinching his cheek hard enough to hurt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now go back to the party and leave it to me. He closes the door, smiling to himself.  Turns to HAGEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When does my daughter leave with her bridegroom?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They'll cut the cake in a few minutes...leave right after that. Your new son-in-law, do we give him something important?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, give him a living.  But never let him know the family's business. What else, Tom?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've called the hospital; they've notified Consiglere Genco's family to come and wait.  He won't last out the night. This saddens the DON.  He sighs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Genco will wait for me.  Santino, tell your brothers they will come with me to the hospital to see Genco.  Tell Fredo to drive the big car, and ask Johnny to come with us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Michael?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All my sons. (to HAGEN) Tom, I want you to go to California tonight.  Make the arrangements. But don't leave until I come back from the hospital and speak to you. Understood?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Understood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MALL (SUMMER 1945) Now all the wedding GUESTS excitedly clap their hands over the entrance of the cake: NAZORINE is beaming as he wheels in a serving table containing the biggest, gaudiest, most extravagant wedding cake ever baked, an incredible monument of his gratitude.  The CROWD is favorably impressed: they begin to clink their knives or forks against their glasses, in the traditional request for the Bride to cut the cake and kiss the Groom.  Louder and louder, five hundred forks hitting five hundred glasses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MALL (SUMMER 1945) Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: late day.  The GUESTS are gone.  A single black car is in the courtyard.  FREDDIE is behind the driver's seat: the DON enters the car, looks at MICHAEL, who sits between SONNY and JOHNNY in the rear seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will your girl friend get back to the city all right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom said he'd take care of it. The DON pulls the door shut; and the car pulls out, through the gate of the great Corleone Mall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : HOSPITAL CORRIDOR (SUMMER 1945) A long white hospital corridor, at the end of which we can see a grouping of FIVE WOMEN, some old and some young, but all plump and dressed in black.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and his SONS move toward the end.  But then the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: slows, putting his hand on MICHAEL's shoulder.  MICHAEL stops and turns toward his FATHER.  The two looks at one another for some time.  SILENCE.  DON CORLEONE then lifts his hand, and slowly touches a particular medal on MICHAEL's uniform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What was this for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For bravery.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For killing a man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What miracles you do for strangers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I fought for my country.  It was my choice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now, what do you choose to do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to finish school.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good.  When you are finished, come and talk to me.  I have hopes for you. Again they regard each other without a word.  MICHAEL turns, and continues on.  DON CORLEONE watches a moment, and then follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : HOSPITAL ROOM (SUMMER 1945) DON CORLEONE enters the hospital room, moving closest to OUR VIEW.  He is followed by his SONS, JOHNNY and the WOMEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Genco, I've brought my sons to pay their respects.  And look, even Johnny Fontane, all the way from Hollywood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is a tiny, wasted skeleton of a man.  DON CORLEONE takes his bony hand, as the others arrange themselves around his bed, each clasping the other hand in turn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Godfather, Godfather, it's your daughter's wedding day, you cannot refuse me.  Cure me, you have the power.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have no such power...but Genco, don't fear death.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's been arranged, then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You blaspheme.  Resign yourself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You need your old Consigliere.  Who will replace me? (suddenly) Stay with me Godfather.  Help me meet death.  If he sees you, he will be frightened and leave me in peace.  You can say a word, pull a few strings, eh?  We'll outwit that bastard as we outwitted all those others. (clutching his hand) Godfather, don't betray me. The DON motions all the others to leave the room.  They do. He returns his attention to GENCO, holding his hand and whispering things we cannot hear, as they wait for death.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : AIRPLANE (SUMMER 1945) FADE IN: The interior of a non-stop Constellation.  HAGEN is one of the very few passengers on this late flight.  He looks like any young lawyer on a business trip.  He is tired from the difficult preparation and duties that he has just executed during the wedding.  On the seat next to him is an enormous, bulging briefcase.  He closes his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : HONEYMOON HOTEL (SUMMER 1945) The honeymoon hotel: CARLO and CONNIE.  CARLO is in his undershorts, sitting up on the bed, anxiously taking the envelopes out of the silk bridal purse and counting the contents.  CONNIE prepares herself in the large marble bathroom.  She rubs her hands over his bronze shoulders, and tries to get his interest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S OFFICE (SUMMER 1945) DON CORLEONE in his office.  LUCA BRASI sitting near to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Luca, I am worried about this man Sollozzo.  Find out what you can, through the Tattaglias.  Let them believe you could be tempted away from the Corleone Family, if the right offer was made.  Learn what he has under his fingernails...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MANCINI APT. HALL (SUMMER 1945) The hallway of an apartment building.  SONNY enters, climbs two steps at a time.  He knocks, and then whispers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's me, Sonny. The door opens, and two lovely arms are around him, pulling him into the apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : LUCA'S ROOM (WINTER 1945) LUCA BRASI's tiny room.  He is partly dressed.  He kneels and reaches under his bed and pulls out a small, locked trunk.  He opens it, and takes out a heavy, bullet-proof vest.  He puts it on, over his wool undershirt, and then puts on his shirt and jacket.  He takes his gun, quickly disassembles, checks, and reassembles it.  And leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S OFFICE (SUMMER 1945) A CLOSE VIEW of DON CORLEONE thinking quietly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MOVING TRAIN (SUMMER 1945)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and KAY on a train, speeding on their way to New Hampshire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : SUBWAY (WINTER 1945) LUCA, in his bulky jacket, sitting quietly on an empty subway train.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : AIRPLANE (SUMMER 1945) HAGEN on the Constellation.  He reaches into his briefcase, and takes out several pictures and papers. One photograph is of a smiling man, JACK WOLTZ, linked arm in arm with fifteen movie stars on either side, including a lovely young child star to his immediate right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: considers other papers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S OFFICE (SUMMER 1945) DON CORLEONE looks, and then moves HAGEN into an embrace. He straightens his arms and looks at TOM deeply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Remember my new Consigliere, a lawyer with his briefcase can steal more than a hundred men with guns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : WOLTZ ESTATE GATE (SUMMER 1945) JACK WOLTZ ESTATE.  HAGEN stands before the impressive gate, armed only with his briefcase.  A GATEMAN opens the gate, and TOM enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : WOLTZ GARDENS (SUMMER 1945) HAGEN and WOLTZ comfortably stroll along beautiful formal gardens, martinis in hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You should have told me your boss was Corleone, Tom, I had to check you out.  I thought you were just some third rate hustler Johnny was running in to bluff me. (a piece of statuary) Florence, thirteenth century. Decorated the garden of a king. They cross the garden and head toward the stables.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to show you something beautiful. They pass the stables, and come to rest by a stall with a huge bronze plaque attached to the outside wall: "KHARTOUM."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: are positioned in chairs nearby; they rise as WOLTZ approaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You like horses?  I like horses, I love 'em.  Beautiful, expensive Racehorses. The animal inside is truly beautiful.  WOLTZ whispers to him with true love in his voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Khartoum...Kartoum...You are looking at six hundred thousand dollars on four hoofs.  I bet even Russian Czars never paid that kind of dough for a single horse.  But I'm not going to race him I'm going to put him out to Stud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : WOLTZ DINING ROOM (SUMMER 1945) HAGEN and WOLTZ sit at an enormous dining room table, attended by SEVERAL SERVANTS.  Great paintings hang on the walls.  The meal is elaborate and sumptuous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Corleone is Johnny's Godfather. That is very close, a very sacred religious relationship.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, but just tell him this is one favor I can't give.  But he should try me again on anything else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He never asks a second favor when he has been refused the first. Understood?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You smooth son of a bitch, let me lay it on the line for you, and your boss.  Johnny Fontane never gets that movie.  I don't care how many Dago, Guinea, wop Greaseball Goombahs come out of the woodwork!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm German-Irish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay my Kraut-Mick friend, Johnny will never get that part because I hate that pinko punk and I'm going to run him out of the Movies.  And I'll tell you why.  He ruined one of Woltz Brothers' most valuable proteges.  For five years I had this girl under training; singing lessons!  Acting lessons!  Dancing lessons!  We spent hundreds of thousands of dollars--I was going to make her a star.  I'll be even more frank, just to show you that I'm not a hard-hearted man, that it wasn't all dollars and cents.  That girl was beautiful and young and innocent and she was the greatest piece of ass I've ever ad and I've had them all over the world.  Then Johnny comes along with that olive oil voice and guinea charm and she runs off.  She threw it all away to make me look ridiculous.  A MAN IN MY POSITION CANNOT AFFORD TO BE MADE TO LOOK RIDICULOUS!
direction.name: direction

result.heading: A MAN IN MY POSITION CANNOT AFFORD TO BE MADE TO LOOK RIDICULOUS

direction.raw_text: : GENCO OLIVE OIL CO. (SUMMER 1945) An unimposing little building in New York City on Mott Street with a large old sign: "GENCO OLIVE OIL IMPORTS, INC." next to an open-faced fruit market. A dark Buick pulls up, and a single small man, whom we cannot see well because of the distance, gets out and enters the building.  This is VIRGIL SOLLOZZO.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: DON, SOLLOZZO, SONNY, HAGEN, FREDDIE, CLEMENZA

direction.raw_text: : OLIVE OIL OFFICES (SUMMER 1945) Looking toward the staircase we can hear SOLLOZZO's footsteps before he actually rises into view.  He is a small man, very dark, with curly black hair.  But wiry, and tight and hard, and obviously very dangerous.  He is greeted at the head of the stairs by SONNY, who takes his hand and shakes it, introducing himself.  For a moment, there is a complex of handshaking quite formal, and whispered respectful introductions.  Finally, SOLLOZZO is taken into the DON's glass paneled office; the two principals are introduced. They are very respectful of one another.  Folding chairs are brought in by FREDDIE, and soon they are all sitting around in a circle; the DON, SOLLOZZO, SONNY, HAGEN, FREDDIE, CLEMENZA and TESSIO.  The DON is the slightest bit foolish with all his compatriots, whereas SOLLOZZO has brought no one.  Throughout all that transpires, however, it is clear that this scene is between two men: SOLLOZZO and DON CORLEONE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My business is heroin, I have poppy fields, laboratories in Narseilles and Sicily, ready to go into production.  My importing methods are as safe as these things can be, about five per cent loss.  The risk is nothing, the profits enormous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why do you come to me?  Why do I deserve your generosity?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need two million dollars in cash...more important, I need a friend who has people in high places; a friend who can guarantee that if one of my employees be arrested, they would get only light sentences.  Be my friend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What percentages for my family?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thirty per cent.  In the first year your share would be four million dollars; then it would go up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what is the percentage of the Tattaglia family?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: nods toward HAGEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My compliments.  I'll take care of them from my share.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So.  I receive 30 per cent just for finance and legal protection.  No worries about operations, is that what you tell me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you think two million dollars in cash is just finance, I congratulate you Don Corleone. There is a long silence; in which each person present feels the tension.  The DON is about to give his answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said I would see you because I've heard you're a serious man, to be treated with respect... (pause) But I'll say no to you. We feel this around the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll give you my reasons.  I have many, many friends in Politics. But they wouldn't be so friendly if my business was narcotics instead of gambling.  They think gambling is something like liquor, a harmless vice...and they think narcotics is dirty business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: takes a breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No...how a man makes his living is none of my business.  But this proposition of yours is too risky. All the people in my family lived well the last ten years, I won't risk that out of greed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you worried about security for your million?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Tattaglias will guarantee your investment also. This startles SONNY; he blurts out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Tattaglia family guarantees our investment?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: hears him first, and then very slowly turns to face him.  Everyone is the room knows that SONNY has stepped out of line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Young people are greedy, and they have no manners.  They speak when they should listen.  But I have a sentimental weakness for my children, and I've spoiled them, as you see.  But Signor Sollozzo, my no is final.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: nods, understands that this is the dismissal.  He glances one last time at SONNY.  He rises; all the others do as well.  He bows to the DON, shakes his hand, and formally takes his leave.  When the footsteps can no longer be heard: The DON turns to SONNY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Santino, never let anyone outside the family know what you are thinking.  I think your brain is going soft from all that comedy you play with that young girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: are carrying an enormous floral display with the word "THANK YOU" spelled out in flowers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is this nonsense?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's from Johnny.  It was announced this morning.  He's going to play the lead in the new Woltz Brothers film.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : WOLTZ'S BEDROOM (SUMMER 1945) It is large, dominated by a huge bed, in which a man, presumably WOLTZ, is sleeping.  Soft light bathes the room from the large windows.  We move closer to him until we see his face, and recognize JACK WOLTZ.  He turns uncomfortably; mutters, feels something strange in his bedsheets.  Something wet. He wakens, feels the sheets with displeasure; they are wet. He looks at his hand; the wetness is blood.  He is frightened, pulls aside the covers, and sees fresh blood on his sheets and pajamas.  He grunts, pulls the puddle of blood in his bed.  He feels his own body frantically, moving, down, following the blood, until he is face to face with the great severed head of Khartoum lying at the foot of his bed.  Just blood from the hacked neck.  White reedy tendons show.  He struggles up to his elbows in the puddle of blood to see more clearly.  Froth covers the muzzle, and the enormous eyes of the animal are yellowed and covered with blood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: tries to scream; but cannot.  No sound comes out. Then, finally and suddenly an ear-splitting scream of pure terror escapes from WOLTZ, who is rocking on his hands and knees in an uncontrolled fit, blood all over him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : OLIVE OIL OFFICES (SUMMER 1945) CLOSE VIEW on the GODFATHER.  Nodding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Send Johnny my congratulations.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (SCENES 12 & 12 OMITTED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : FIFTH AVENUE (WINTER 1945) Fifth Avenue in the snow.  Christmas week.  People are bundled up with rosy faces, rushing to buy presents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and MICHAEL exit a Fifth Avenue department store, carrying a stack of gaily wrapped gifts, arm in arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have something for your mother, for Sonny, we have the tie for Fredo and Tom Hagen gets the Reynolds pen...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what do you want for Christmas?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just you. They kiss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : HOTEL ROOM (WINTER 1945) CLOSE ON a wooden radio, playing quiet Music.  THE VIEW PANS
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the dark hotel room, curtained against the daylight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll have a quiet, civil ceremony at the City Hall, no big fuss, no family, just a couple of friends as witnesses. The two are in each other's arms in a mess of bedsheets on the two single beds that they have pushed together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What will your father say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As long as I tell him beforehand he won't object.  He'll be hurt, but he won't object.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What time do they expect us?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For dinner.  Unless I call and tell them we're still in New Hampshire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Michael.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then we can have dinner, see a show, and spend one more night. He moves to the telephone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Operator.  Get me (fill in number)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Michael, what are you doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shhh, you be the long distance operator.  Here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello...this is Long Distance.  I have a call from New Hampshire.  Mr. Michael Corleone.  One moment please. She hands the phone to MICHAEL who continues the deception.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Tom?  Michael.  Yeah... listen, we haven't left yet.  I'm driving down to the city with Kay tomorrow morning.  There's something important I want to tell the old man before Christmas.  Will he be home tomorrow night?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : OLIVE OIL OFFICE (WINTER 1945) HAGEN in the Olive Oil Company office.  In the background, through the glass partitions, we can see the DON, at work in his office.  TOM is tired, and steeped in paperwork.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure.  Anything I can do for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  I guess I'll see you Christmas. Everyone's going to be out at Long Beach, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right. He smiles.  MICHAEL has hung up.  He looks at the piles of work, and can't face it.  He rises, puts on his coat and hat, and continues out. He peeks into the DON's office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Michael called; he's not leaving New Hampshire until tomorrow morning.  I've got to go, I promised Theresa I'd pick up some toys for the kids. The DON smiles and nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: smiles, and leaves; OUR VIEW remaining with DON CORLEONE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is sitting on a bench in the corner, reading the afternoon paper.  He puts aside the papers the office manager has prepared for him, and then moves to FREDDIE, raps his knuckles on his head to take his nose out of the paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell Paulie to get the car from the lot; I'll be ready to go home in a few minutes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll have to get it myself; Paulie called in sick this morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the third time this month. I think maybe you'd better get a healthier bodyguard for me.  Tell Tom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paulie's a good kid.  If he's sick, he's sick.  I don't mind getting the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: leaves.  He slowly puts on his jacket.  Looks out his window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : OLIVE OIL CO. (WINTER 1945)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: crosses the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : OLIVE OIL OFFICE (WINTER 1945) OFFICE MANAGER Buon Watale, Don Corleone. The MANAGER helps him on with his overcoat.  Once again, the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: glances out his window. The black car pulls up; FREDDIE driving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merry Christmas. (handing the MANAGER an envelope) And he starts down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : OLIVE OIL CO. (WINTER 1945) The light outside is very cold, and beginning to fail.  When
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: sees his FATHER coming, he moves back into the driver's seat.  The DON moves to the car, and is about to get in when he hesitates, and turns back to the long, open fruit stand near the corner. The PROPRIETOR springs to serve him.  The DON walks among the trays and baskets, and merely points to a particular piece of fruit.  As he selects, the MAN gingerly picks the pieces of fruit up and puts them into a paper bag.  The DON pays with a five dollar bill, waits for his change, and then turns back to the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : POLKS TOY STORE (WINTER 1945) TOM HAGEN exits carrying a stack of presents, all gift wrapped.  He continues past the windows.  As he walks, someone walks right in his way.  He looks up.  It is SOLLOZZO. He takes TOM by the arm and walks along with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be frightened.  I just want to talk to you. A car parked at the curb suddenly flings its rear door open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get in; I want to talk to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pulls his arm free.  He is frightened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I haven't got time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: suddenly appear on either side of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get in the car.  If I wanted to kill you you'd be dead already. Trust me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: sick to his stomach, moves with his ESCORTS, leaving our VIEW on the Mechanical windows gaily bobbing the story of Hansel and Gretel.  We HEAR the car doors shut, and the car drive off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : RADIO CITY - PHONE BOOTH (WINTER 1945) RADIO CITY MUSIC HALL during the Christmas show.  KAY and
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: exit; tears are still streaming down her cheeks, and she sniffles, and dries her tears with Kleenex.  KAY nostalgically hums "The Bells of Saint Mary's," as they walk arm in arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you like me better if I were a nun?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you like me better if I were Ingrid Bergman? They have passed a little enclosed newsstand.  KAY sees something that terrifies her.  She doesn't know what to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: still walks, thinking about her question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Michael?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm thinking about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Michael...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I would not like you better if you were Ingrid Bergman. She cannot answer him.  Rather she pulls him by the arm, back to the newsstand, and points.  His face goes grave. The headlines read: "VITO CORLEONE SHOT, CHIEFTAN GUNNED DOWN."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is petrified; quickly he takes each edition, drops a dollar in the tray, and hungrily reads through them.  KAY knows to remain silent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They don't say if he's dead or alive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : OLIVE OIL CO. (WINTER 1945)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: by the fruit stand; he is about to move to the car, when TWO MEN step from the corner.  Suddenly, the DON drops the bag of fruit and darts with startling quickness toward the parked car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fredo, Fredo! The paper bag has hit the ground, and the fruit begins rolling along the sidewalk, as we HEAR gunshots. Five bullets catch the DON in the back; he arches in pain, and continues toward the car. The PROPRIETOR of the fruit stand rushes for cover, knocking over an entire case of fruit. The TWO GUNMEN move in quickly, anxious to finish him off. Their feet careful to avoid the rolling fruit.  There are more GUNSHOTS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is hysterical; he tries to get out of the car; having difficulty opening the door.  He rushes out, a gun trembling in his hand; his mouth open.  He actually drops the gun. The gun falls amid the rolling fruit. The GUNMEN are panicked.  They fire once more at the downed
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .  His leg and arm twitch where they are hit; and pools of blood are beginning to form. The GUNMEN are obviously in a state of panic and confusion; they disappear around the corner as quickly as they came. The PEOPLE about the avenue have all but disappeared: rather, we catch glimpses of them, poking their heads safely from around corners, inside doorways and arches, and from windows.  But the street itself is now empty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is in shock; he looks at his FATHER; now great puddles of blood have formed, and the DON is lifeless and face down in them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: falls back on to the curb and sits there, saying something we cannot understand.  He begins to weep profusely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : SUBWAY (WINTER 1945) LUCA BRASI riding alone on a subway car, late at night.  He gets off. He emerges at a subway terminal, proceeds out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : NIGHT CLUB STREET (WINTER 1945) LUCA walks down the late night street.  He approaches an elegant New York Nightclub, whose gaudy neon sign is still winking this late at night.  He waits and watches.  Then the sign goes out; and he proceeds into the club.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : NIGHTCLUB (WINTER 1945) The main floor of the Nightclub is very large, with endless glistening wooden floors.  Now, at this late time, the chairs have been stacked on the tables and a NEGRO JANITOR is waxing them.  A single HAT-CHECK GIRL is counting her receipts.  LUCA moves past the empty bandstand, and sits at the bar.  ANOTHER MAN, dark and very well-built, moves behind the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Luca...I'm Bruno Tattaglia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks up; and out of the shadows emerges SOLLOZZO.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know who I am?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've been talking to the Tattaglias.  They thought we could do business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: listens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need somebody strong to protect my operation, physically.  I've heard you're not happy with your family, you might make a switch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If the money is good enough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the first shipment, I can guarantee you fifty thousand dollars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks at him; he had no idea the offer would be so good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: extends his hand, but LUCA pretends not to see it, rather, he busies himself putting a cigarette in his mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: behind the bar, makes a cigarette lighter magically appear, and holds it to LUCA's cigarette.  Then, he does an odd thing; he drops the lighter on the bar, and puts his hand lightly on LUCA's, almost patting it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : SONNY'S LIVING ROOM (WINTER 1945) The telephone in SONNY's house is ringing.  He approaches it, obviously fresh from a nap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you recognize my voice?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think so.  Detective squad?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right.  Don't say my name, just listen.  Somebody shot your father outside his place fifteen minutes ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is he alive?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think so, but I can't get close enough.  There's a lot of blood. I'll try to find out more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Find out anything you can...you got a Grand coming. (click)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: cradles the phone.  An incredible rage builds up in him, his face actually turning red.  He would like to rip the phone to pieces in his bare hands.  Then he controls it. Quickly, he dials another number.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Theresa, let me talk to Tom.  Not yet?  Have him call me as soon as he gets home. He hangs up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sonny?  Sonny, who is it? (she enters the room) What is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They shot the old man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh God...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honey...don't worry.  Nothing else is going to happen. There is a POUNDING on the door.  A BABY starts crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: reaches into a cabinet drawer, takes out a gun, and moves quickly.  He opens the front door quickly.  It is
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .  He enters, SONNY closes the door.  SANDRA goes to look after the baby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You heard about your father?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The word is out in the streets that he's dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where the hell was Paulie, why wasn't he with the Don?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paulie's been a little sick all winter...he was home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How many times did he stay home the last couple of months?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe three, four times.  I always asked Freddie if he wanted another bodyguard, but he said no.  Things have been so smooth the last ten years...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go get Paulie, I don't care how sick he is.  Pick him up yourself, and bring him to my father's house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's all?  Don't you want me to send some people over here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, just you and Paulie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: leaves; SONNY moves to SANDRA, who sits on the couch weeping quietly, comforting her BABY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A couple of our people will come to stay here.  Do whatever they say; I'm going over to the main house. If you want me, use Pop's special phone. The telephone rings again.  SONNY answers it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Santino Corleone?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: moves behind him, anxious to know who it is.  SONNY indicates that she be quiet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have Tom Hagen.  In about three hours he'll be released with our proposition.  Don't do anything until you've heard what he has to say.  You can only cause a lot of trouble.  What's done is done. (a pause) Don't lose that famous temper of yours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll wait.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MALL (WINTER 1945) FULL VIEW OF THE CORLEONE MALL.  It is night, but the courtyard is bathed with white light from floodlights on the tops of all the houses.  It is very cold.  We see the figure of SONNY cross the Mall, and let himself into the main house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S KITCHEN (WINTER 1945) SONNY walks into the empty, darkened house.  Then he calls out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ma?  Ma, where are you. The kitchen door swings open.  He moves quickly and takes her by the arm.  He is deliberately calm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ma, I just got a call.  Pop's hurt...I don't know how bad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Santino?  Have they killed him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We don't know yet, Ma.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll get dressed.  In case we can see him... She moves out of the kitchen, and continues upstairs.  SONNY turns the gas from the pan of peppers she was frying.  He takes some bread without thinking, and dips it in the oil, and sloppily eats some of the peppers, as he moves into his father's office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S OFFICE (WINTER 1945) He switches the lights on in the DON's office.  The massive desk dominates the room.  SONNY moves quickly to the telephone, pulling a small chair to the side of the desk, and dials a number.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tessio...This is Santino Corleone. I want fifty reliable men out here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heard, Sonny...but what about Clemenza's regime?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want to use Clemenza's people right now.  Understood? He hangs up.  He moves quickly to a wall safe; operates the dial, and removes a small notebook.  He takes it back to the desk, and runs over the list of numbers with his forefinger. We follow the names, until the finger stops at one: LUCA BRASI.  SONNY dials the number.  There is no answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Luca.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : BUILDING (WINTER 1945) The interior of an abandoned building.  SEVERAL MEN in suits and ties sit around in the booths.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: sits in one: SOLLOZZO sits across from him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know you're not in the muscle end of the family--so I don't want you to be afraid.  I want you to help the Corleones and I want you to help me. HAGEN's hands are trembling as he tries to put a cigarette in his mouth.  ONE of the BUTTON MEN brings a bottle of rye to the table, and pours a little into a delicate, flowered china cup.  HAGEN sips gratefully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your boss is dead...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is overwhelmed: actual tears spring to his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pauses respectfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have some more.  We got him outside his office, just before I picked you up.  You have to make the peace between me and Santino.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: still is focused on the grief of losing the old man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sonny was hot for my deal, right? You know it's the smart thing to do, too.  I want you to talk Sonny into it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sonny will come after you with everything he's got.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: rises, impatiently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's going to be his first reaction.  You have to talk some sense into him.  The Tattaglia family stands behind me with all their people.  The other New York Families will go along with anything that prevents a full scale war. He leans close to HAGEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Don was slipping; in the old days I could never have gotten to him.  Now he's dead, nothing can bring him back.  Talk to Sonny, talk to the Caporegimes, Clemenza and Tessio...it's good business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Even Sonny won't be able to call off Luca Brasi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll worry about Luca.  You take care of Sonny and the other two kids.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll try...It's what the Don would want us to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good...then you can go... (he escorts him to the door) I don't like violence.  I'm a businessman, and blood is a big expense. He opens the door; they step out together.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (lifting his hands in an expression of harmlessness)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : BUILDING HAGEN, SOLLOZZO exit. But a car pulls up, and ONE of SOLLOZZO'S MEN rushes out. He indicates with some urgency that he wants to talk to
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in private. Then SOLLOZZO moves with a grave expression.  He opens the door, indicating that HAGEN should be led back in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The old man is still alive.  Five bullets in his Sicilian hide and he's still alive. (he gives a fatalistic shrug) Bad luck for me, bad luck for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MALL (WINTER 1945) MICHAEL driving during the night.  There is a little fog in the air, and moisture has formed on the windshield, making it difficult to see well.  The wipers move across the view, as the gate of the Corleone Mall appears before us, still decorated for Christmas.  The courtyard is bathed with white floodlight, giving this place a cold and isolated look.  The narrow entrance mouth of the Mall is sealed off with a link chain.  There are strange cars parked along the curving cement walk.  SEVERAL MEN are congregated about the gate and chain; ONE of them approaches MICHAEL's car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who're you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: peeks his ugly face almost right up to MICHAEL, and then turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's the Don's kid; take the car, I'll bring him inside. The FIRST MAN opens the car door, and MICHAEL steps out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : HALL (WINTER 1945) The Hallway of the main house is filled with MEN MICHAEL doesn't recognize.  They pay little attention to him.  Most of them are waiting; sitting uncomfortably; no one is talking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S LIVING ROOM (WINTER 1945) MICHAEL moves into the living room; there is a Christmas tree, and countless greeting cards taped to the walls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is sitting stiffly on the sofa, smoking a cigarette; on the coffee table in front of her is a water glass half filled with whiskey.  On the other side of the sofa sits CLEMENZA; his face is impassive, but he is sweating, and the cigar in his hand glistens slickly black with his saliva.  PAULIE GATTO sits tensely and alone on the other side of the room.  CLEMENZA sees MICHAEL, looks up at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your mother's at the hospital with the old man: He's gonna pull through.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: nods his relief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks. He moves to THERESA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You heard from Tom yet? Without looking up, she clings to him for a moment, and trembles.  Occasionally, STRANGE MEN will cross through the room; everyone speaks in a whisper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mon. He leads her into his father's office without knocking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S OFFICE (WINTER 1945) SONNY and TESSIO are huddled around a yellow pad.  They look up, startled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry, Theresa; they just want to give Tom the proposition, then they're going to turn him loose. He reassuringly hugs THERESA, and then to MICHAEL's surprise, he kisses him on the cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was worried when we couldn't get in touch with you in that hick town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's Mom?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good.  She's been through it before. Me too.  You were too young to know about it.  You better wait outside; there're some things you shouldn't hear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can help you out...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh no you can't, the old man'd be sore as hell if I let you get mixed up in this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus Christ, he's my father, Sonny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Theresa. She understands, and leaves them alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, Mikey...who do we have to hit, Clemenza or Paulie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One of them fingered the old man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: didn't realize that the men waiting outside were on trial for their lives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clemenza?  No, I don't believe it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right, kid, Clemenza is okay. It was Paulie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can you be sure?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the three days Paulie was sick this month, he got calls from a payphone across from the old man's building.  We got people in the phone company. (he shrugs) Thank God it was Paulie...we'll need Clemenza bad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is just realizing the gravity and extent of the situation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is it going to be all-out war, like last time?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Until the old man tells me different.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then wait, Sonny.  Talk to Pop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sollozzo is a dead man, I don't care what it costs.  I don't care if we have to fight all the five families in New York.  The Tattaglia family's going to eat dirt.  I don't care if we all go down together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's not how Pop would have played it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know I'm not the man he was.  But I'll tell you this and he'll tell you too.  When it comes to real action, I can operate as good as anybody short range.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, Sonny.  All right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christ, if I could only contact Luca.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is it like they say?  Is he that good? Outside, we HEAR THERESA cry out, almost a scream of relief. Then open the door and rush out. Everyone is standing: in the doorway, TOM HAGEN is wrapped in a tight embrace with his WIFE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I plead before the Supreme Court, I'll never do better than I did tonight with that Turk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MALL, FEATURING DON'S HOUSE (WINTER 1945) The windows of the main house are dark except for the DON's study.  It stands out against the cold, dark night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S LIVING ROOM (WINTER 1945) The living room is empty, save for PAULIE GATTO sitting on the edge of the sofa.  The clock reads: 4:00 a.m.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S OFFICE (WINTER 1945) SONNY, MICHAEL, HAGEN, CLEMENZA and TESSIO; all exhausted, in shirtsleeves, about to fall asleep.  It is four in the morning; there is evidence of many cups of coffee and many snacks.  They can barely talk anymore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is the hospital covered?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cops have it locked in and I got my people there visiting Pop all the time.  What about the hit list.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: widens his sleepy eyes, and looks at the yellow pad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too much, too far, too personal. The Don would consider this all purely a business dispute: Get rid of Sollozzo, and everything falls in line.  YOU don't have to go after the Tattaglias.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about Luca?  Sollozzo didn't seem worried about Luca.  That worries me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If Luca sold out we're in real trouble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Has anyone been able to get in touch with him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, and I've been calling all night. Maybe he's shacked up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Luca never sleeps over with a broad. He always goes home when he's through.  Mike, keep ringing Luca's number.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: very tired, picks up the phone, and dials the number once again.  He can hear the phone ringing on the other end but no one answers.  Then hangs up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Keep trying every fifteen minutes. (exhausted)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom, you're the Consigliere, what do we do if the old man dies?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Without your father's political contacts and personal influence, the Corleone family loses half its strength.  Without your father, the other New York families might wind up supporting Sollozzo, and the Tattaglias just to make sure there isn't a long destructive war.  The old days are over, this is 1946; nobody wants bloodshed anymore.  If your father dies...make the deal, Sonny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's easy to say; it's not your father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was as good a son to him as you or Mike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh Christ Tom, I didn't mean it that way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're all tired...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: we sit tight until the old man can give us the lead.  But Tom, I want you to stay inside the Mall. You too, Mike, no chances.  Tessio, you hold your people in reserve, but have them nosing around the city.  The hospital is yours; I want it tight, fool-proof, 24 hours a day. There is a timid knock on the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I tol' you to stay put, Paulie...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The guy at the gate's outside...says there's a package...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tessio, see what it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: gets up, leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want me to hang around?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.  Hang around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Outside?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. He closes the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clemenza.  You take care of Paulie. I don't ever want to see him again. Understood?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Understood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, now you can move your men into the Mall, replace Tessio's people.  Mike, tomorrow you take a couple of Clemenza's people and go to Luca's apartment and wait for him to show.  That crazy bastard might be going after Sollozzo right now if he's heard the news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe Mike shouldn't get mixed up in this so directly.  You know the old man doesn't want that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: forget it, just stay on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is embarrassed to be so protected.  He dials Luca Brasi's number once again.  The ring repeats, but no one answers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: comes back, carrying Luca Brasi's bullet-proof vest in his hand.  He unwraps it; there is a large fish wrapped inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sicilian message: Luca Brasi sleeps with the fishes.
direction.name: direction
