direction.raw_text: : NIGHTCLUB (WINTER 1945) LUCA sits at the Bar of the Tattaglia Nightclub, as we remember him.  BRUNO TATTAGLIA had just patted his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks up at him. Then SOLLOZZO pats the other hand, almost affectionately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is just about to twist his hands away, when they both clamp down as hard as they can.  Suddenly, a garrote is thrown around his neck, and pulled violently tight.  His face begins to turn to purple blotches, and then totally purple, right before our eyes; his tongue hangs out, in a far more extreme way than a normal tongue could.  His eyes bulge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of the MEN looks down at him in disgust as LUCA's strength leaves him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh Christ...all over the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: lets LUCA's hand go with a victorious smile on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: falls to the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Godfather is next.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : CLEMENZA'S HOUSE (WINTER 1945) Morning in a simple Brooklyn suburb.  There are rows of pleasant houses; driveway after driveway, down the block.  A dark, somber young man of thirty-one or two walks with a noticeable limp down the sidewalk, and rings the bell.  This is ROCCO LAMPONE.  The woman of the house, MRS. CLEMENZA, talks to him through the screen door, and then points to the side of the house.  ROCCO moves to the garage, which is specially heated, and in which CLEMENZA is busy at work washing a shiny brand new Lincoln.  LAMPONE admires the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crazy Detroit delivered it with a wooden bumper.  They're going to send me the chrome bumpers in a couple months.  I waited two years for this car to come with wooden bumpers! He scrubs and polishes with great affection.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Today you make your bones on Paulie. You understand everything?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. As he scrubs around the glove compartment, he opens it, unwraps a gun and gives it to LAMPONE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .22 soft-nosed load.  Accurate up to five feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: expertly puts the gun away.  GATTO's car pulls into the driveway, and he sounds the horn. The two men walk to the car.  GATTO is driving, a bit nervous, like he doesn't know what is up.  LAMPONE gets in the rear seat; CLEMENZA in the front, making a grunt of recognition.  He looks at his wristwatch, as though wanting to chide PAULIE for being late.  PAULIE flinches a little when he sees LAMPONE will ride behind him; he half turns:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rocco, sit on the other side.  A big guy like you blocks my rearview mirror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: turns sourly to PAULIE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goddamn Sonny.  He's running scared. He's already thinking of going to the mattresses.  We have to find a place on the West Side.  Paulie, you know a good location?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: relaxes a bit; he thinks he's off any possible hook he was on.  Also there's the money he can make by selling Sollozzo any secret location.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll think about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Drive while you thinking; I wanna get to the City this month! The car pulls out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : PAULIE'S CAR - ON ROAD (WINTER 1945) Inside PAULIE drives; and CLEMENZA sits in a grump.  OUR VIEW does not show LAMPONE in the rear seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : PAULIE'S CAR AT TUNNEL (WINTER 1945) The Car crosses to the Midtown Tunnel in the late Winter light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : PAULIE'S CAR IN TUNNEL (WINTER 1945) Inside the tunnel; GATTO doesn't like not seeing LAMPONE. He tries to adjust his rearview mirror to catch a glimpse of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pay attention!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : PAULIE'S CAR AT MATTRESS (WINTER 1945) The car is parked in the City.  PAULIE comes down from an available apartment and gets back into the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good for ten men...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: go to Arthur Avenue; I'm suppose to call when I found somethin'. The car pulls off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : RESTAURANT (WINTER 1945) New part of the city; the car pulls up in a parking lot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: get outs, glances at LAMPONE, then to PAULIE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You wait; I'll call. He walks, tucking his shirt into his pants, around the corner and enters the Luna Restaurant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : RESTAURANT (WINTER 1945) CLEMENZA enters the little restaurant, sits down at a table. The WAITERS know him; immediately put a bottle of wine, some bread--and then a plate of veal on his table.  He eats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : RESTAURANT (WINTER 1945) CLEMENZA exits the restaurant, belches, adjusts his pants; he is well fed. We move with him around the corner, not knowing what to expect has happened to Paulie. There is the car; PAULIE is still sitting behind the wheel,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in the rear seat.  CLEMENZA steps in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He talked my ear off.  Want us to go back to Long Beach; have another job for us.  Rocco, you live in the City, can we drop you off?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah, I left my car at your place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: then you gotta come back. The car pulls out.  By now, PAULIE is completely relaxed and secure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think we'll go for that last place?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe, or you gotta know now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holy cow, I don't gotta know nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : PAULIE'S CAR ON CAUSEWAY (WINTER 1945) The car moves along the ready beach area of the causeway. Inside, CLEMENZA turns to PAULIE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paulie, pull over.  I gotta take a leak. The car pulls off the Causeway, into the reeds.  CLEMENZA steps out of the car, OUR VIEW MOVING with him. He turns his back three quarters from us (we can no longer see the car), unzips, and we hear the sound of urine hitting the ground.  We wait on this for a moment; and then there are two GUNSHOTS.  CLEMENZA finishes his leak, zips up and turns, moving back to the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is dead, bleeding from the mouth; the windows behind him are shattered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leave the gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: gets out, the two men walk through the reeds a few feet where there is another car.  They get in, and drive off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MALL (WINTER 1945) HIGH ANGLE OF THE MALL.  It is late afternoon.  Many strange cars are parked on the nearby streets.  We can see the group of BUTTON MEN, stationed here and there, obviously sentries with concealed weapons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: walks along in the rear yard. He is bundled in a warm marine coat.  He looks at the strange men, regarding them with an uncertain awe.  They look back at him, at first suspiciously and then with the respect of his position.  He is like an exile Prince.  He wanders past them, and hesitates and looks at the yard. A rusted set of garden swings; and other home playground equipment.  The basketball ring now half coming off.  This is where he was a child.  Then a shout.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mike.  Hey Mikey; telephone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: had shouted from the kitchen window.  MICHAEL hurries into the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S KITCHEN (WINTER 1945) CLEMENZA is in the kitchen, cooking over an enormous pot. He points to the kitchen wall phone which is hanging off the hook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some dame.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: picks it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello.  Kay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How is your father?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'll be OK.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you. He glances at the THUGS in the kitchen.  Tries to shield the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah Kay, I'm here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you say it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me you love me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: glances at the HOODS at the kitchen table.  He curls up in a corner, and in a quarter voice:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please say it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look.  I'll see you tonight, OK?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . (click)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is getting ready to build a tomato sauce for all the button men stationed around the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How come you don't tell that nice girl you love her...here, learn something... you may have to feed fifty guys some day.  You start with olive oil...fry some garlic, see.  And then fry some sausage...or meat balls if you like...then you throw in the tomatoes, the tomato paste...some basil; and a little red wine...that's my trick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: peeks into the kitchen; sees CLEMENZA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You take care of Paulie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You won't see Paulie anymore.  He's sick for good this winter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: starts to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To the city.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Send some bodyguards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't need them, Sonny.  I'm just going to see Pop in the hospital. Also, I got other things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sollozzo knows Mike's a civilian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: but be careful.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Clemenza; dipping bread into the sauce)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : CAR MICHAEL sits in the rear seat, calmly, as he is being driven into the city.  THREE BUTTONMEN are crowded into the front seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : HOTEL LOBBY MICHAEL crosses the lobby, past lines of servicemen trying to book rooms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : HOTEL MICHAEL and KAY eating a quiet dinner at the hotel.  He is preoccupied, she's concerned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Visiting hour ends at eight thirty. I'll just sit with him; I want to show respect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I go to the hospital with you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think so.  You don't want to end up on page 3 of the Daily News.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My parents don't read the Daily News.  All right, if you think I shouldn't.  I can't believe the things the papers are printing. I'm sure most of it's not true.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think so either. (silence) I better go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When will I see you again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want you to go back to New Hampshire...think things over. He leans over her; kisses her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When will I see you again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodbye. Quietly, he moves out the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: lies on the bed a while, and then, to herself:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodbye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S HOSPITAL (WINTER 1945) A taxi pulls up in front of a hospital, marked clearly with a neon sign "HOSPITAL--EMERGENCY."  MICHAEL steps out, pays the fare...and then stops dead in his tracks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks. He sees the hospital in the night; but it is deserted.  He is the only one on the street.  There are gay, twinkling Christmas decorations all over the building.  He walks, slowly at first, and then ever so quickly, up the steps.  He hesitates, looks around.  This area is empty.  He checks the address on a scrap of paper.  It is correct.  He tries the door, it is empty. He walks in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : HOSPITAL LOBBY (WINTER 1945) MICHAEL stands in the center of an absolutely empty hospital lobby.  He looks to the right; there is a long, empty corridor.  To the left: the same.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: , as MICHAEL walks through the desolated building lit by eerie green neon lighting.  All we hear are his sole footsteps. He walks up to a desk marked "INFORMATION".  No one is there. He moves quickly to a door marked "OFFICE"; swings into it; no one is there.  He looks onto the desk:  There is half a sandwich, and a half-filled bottle of coke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello?  Hello? Now he knows something is happening, he moves quickly, alertly.  MICHAEL walking down the hospital corridors; all alone.  The floors have just been mopped.  They are still wet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : HOSPITAL STAIRS Now he turns onto a staircase; ever quickening; up several flights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 4TH FLOOR CORRIDOR He steps out onto the fourth floor.  He looks.  There are merely empty corridors.  He takes out his scrap of paper; checks it.  "Room 4A."  Now he hurries, trying to follow the code of hospital rooms; following the right arrows, quicker and quicker they flash by him.  Now he stops, looks up "4A-- Corleone". There is a special card table set up there with some magazines...and some smoking cigarettes still in the ashtray--but no detectives, no police, no bodyguards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S ROOM 4A Slowly he pushes the door open, almost afraid at what he will find.  He looks.  Lit by the moonlight through the window, he can see a FIGURE in the hospital bed alone in the room, and under a transparent oxygen tent.  All that can be heard is the steady though strained breathing.  Slowly
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: walks up to it, and is relieved to see his FATHER, securely asleep.  Tubes hang from a steel gallows beside the bed, and run to his nose and mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing here? This startles MICHAEL; who almost jumps around.  It is a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: lit from the light behind her in the hallway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not supposed to be here now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: calms himself, and moves to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm Michael Corleone--this is my father.  What happened to the detectives who were guarding him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh your father just had too many visitors.  It interfered with the hospital service.  The police came and made them all leave just ten minutes ago. (comfortingly) But don't worry.  I look in on him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You just stand here one minute... Quickly he moves to the telephone, dials a number.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sonny...Sonny--Jesus Christ, I'm down at the hospital.  I came down late.  There's no one here.  None of Tessio's people--no detectives, no one.  The old man is completely unprotected.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, get him in a different room; lock the door from the inside. I'll have some men there inside of fifteen minutes.  Sit tight, and don't panic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I won't panic. He hangs up; returns to the NURSE...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You cannot stay here...I'm sorry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You and I are going to move my father right now...to another room on another floor...Can you disconnect those tubes so we can wheel the bed out?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Absolutely not!  We have to get permission from the Doctor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've read about my father in the papers.  You've seen that no one's here to guard him.  Now I've just gotten word that men are coming to this hospital to kill him.  Believe me and help me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We don't have to disconnect them, we can wheel the stand with the bed. She does so...and they perform the very difficult task of moving the bed and the apparatus, out of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 4TH FLOOR HOSPITAL (WINTER 1945) They roll the bed, the stand, and all the tubes silently down the corridor.  We hear FOOTSTEPS coming up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: hears them, stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hurry, into there. They push it into the first available room.  MICHAEL peeks out from the door.  The footsteps are louder; then they emerge.  It is ENZO, NAZORINE's helper, carrying a bouquet of flowers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Michael...do you remember me, Enzo, the baker's helper to Nazorine, now his son-in-law.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Enzo, get out of here.  There's going to be trouble. A look of fear sweeps through ENZO's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If there...will be trouble...I stay with you, to help.  I owe it to the Godfather.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: thinks, realizes he needs all the help he can get.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go outside; stand in front...I'll be out in a minute.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S SECOND HOSPITAL ROOM (WINTER 1945) They part.  MICHAEL moves into the hospital room where they put his FATHER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's awake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks at the OLD MAN, his eyes are open, though he cannot speak.  MICHAEL touches his face tenderly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pop...Pop, it's me Michael.  Shhhh, don't try to speak.  There are men who are coming to try to kill you. But I'm with you...I'm with you now... The OLD MAN tries to speak...but cannot.  MICHAEL tenderly puts his finger to his FATHER's lips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S HOSPITAL STREET (WINTER 1945) Outside the hospital is empty save for a nervous ENZO, pacing back and forth brandishly the flowers as his only weapon.  MICHAEL exits the hospital and moves to him.  They both stand under a lamppost in the cold December night. They are both frightened; MICHAEL gives ENZO a cigarette, lights it.  ENZO's hands are trembling, MICHAEL's are not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get rid of those and look like you've got a gun in your pocket. The windows of the hospital twinkle with Christmas decorations.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen... We HEAR the sound of a single automobile coming.  MICHAEL and ENZO look with fear in their eyes.  Then MICHAEL takes the bouquet of flowers and stuffs them under his jacket. They stand, hands in their pockets. A long low black car turns the corner and cruises by them. MICHAEL's and ENZO's faces are tough, impassive.  The car seems as though it will stop; and then quickly accelerates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and ENZO are relieved.  MICHAEL looks down; the BAKER's hands are shaking.  He looks at his own, and they are not. Another moment goes by and we can hear the distant sound of police sirens.  They are clearly coming toward the hospital, getting louder and louder.  MICHAEL heaves a sigh of relief. In a second, a patrol car makes a screaming turn in front of the hospital; then two more squad cars follow with uniformed
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and DETECTIVES.  He smiles his relief and starts toward them.  TWO huge, burly POLICEMEN suddenly grab his arms while ANOTHER frisks him.  A massive POLICE CAPTAIN, spattered with gold braid and scrambled eggs on his hat, with beefy red face and white hair seems furious.  This is McCLUSKEY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought I got all you guinea hoods locked up.  Who the hell are you and what are you doing here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: standing nearby:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's clean, Captain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: studies McCLUSKEY closely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened to the detectives who were supposed to be guarding my father?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You punk-hood.  Who the hell are you to tell me my business.  I pulled them off.  I don't care how many Dago gangsters kill each other. I wouldn't lift a finger to keep your old man from getting knocked off.  Now get the hell out of here; get off this street you punk, and stay away from this hospital.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stands quiet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll stay until you put guards around my father's room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil, lock this punk up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid's clean, Captain...He's a war hero, and he's never been mixed up in the rackets...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goddam it, I said lock him up.  Put the cuffs on him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How much is the Turk paying you to set my father up, Captain? Without any warning, McCLUSKEY leans back and hits MICHAEL squarely on the jaw with all his weight and strength.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (deliberately, right to McCLUSKEY's face, as he's being handcuffed)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: groans, and lifts his hand to his jaw.  He looks at McCLUSKEY; we are his VIEW and everything goes spinning, and he falls to the ground, just as we see HAGEN and CLEMENZA'S MEN arrive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MALL (WINTER 1945) HIGH ANGLE VIEW of THE CORLEONE MALL.  The gateway now has a long black car blocking it.  There are more BUTTON MEN stationed more formally; and some of them visibly carrying rifles; those of the houses close to the courtyard have MEN standing by open windows.  It is clear that the war is escalating.  A car pulls up and out get CLEMENZA, LAMPONE, MICHAEL and HAGEN.  MICHAEL's jaw is wired and bandaged.  He stops and looks up at the open window.  We can see MEN holding rifles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christ, Sonny really means business. They continue walking.  TESSIO joins them.  The various
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: make no acknowledgment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How come all the new men?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll need them now.  After the hospital incident, Sonny got mad. We hit Bruno Tattaglia four o'clock this morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S HALLWAY They enter the house past the scores of new and strange faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S OFFICE (WINTER 1945) SONNY is in the DON's office; he is excited and exuberant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got a hundred button men on the streets twenty-four hours a day. If Sollozzo shows one hair on his ass he's dead. He sees MICHAEL, and holds his bandaged face in his hand, kiddingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mikey, you look beautiful!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cut it out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Turk wants to talk!  The nerve of that son of a bitch!  After he craps out last night he wants a meet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Was there a definite proposal?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, he wants us to send Mike to meet him to hear his proposition. The promise is the deal will be so good we can't refuse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about that Tattaglias?  What will they do about Bruno?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Part of the deal: Bruno cancels out what they did to my father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We should hear what they have to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no Consiglere.  Not this time. No more meetings, no more discussions, no more Sollozzo tricks.  Give them one message: I WANT SOLLOZZO.  If not, it's all out war.  We go to the mattresses and we put all the button men out on the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The other families won't sit still for all out war.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then THEY hand me Sollozzo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come ON Sonny, your father wouldn't want to hear this.  This is not a personal thing, this is Business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And when they shot me father...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, even the shooting of your father was business, not personal...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No no, no more advice on how to patch it up Tom.  You just help me win.  Understood?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: bows his head; he is deeply concerned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I found out about this Captain McCluskey who broke Mike's jaw. He's definitely on Sollozzo's payroll, and for big money. McCluskey's agreed to be the Turk's bodyguard.  What you have to understand is that while Sollozzo is guarded like this, he's invulnerable.  Nobody has ever gunned down a New York Police Captain.  Never.  It would be disastrous.  All the five families would come after you Sonny; the Corleone family would be outcasts; even the old man's political protection would run for cover.  So just...take that into consideration.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: McCluskey can't stay with the Turk forever.  We'll wait.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can't wait.  No matter what Sollozzo say about a deal, he's figuring out how to kill Pop.  You have to get Sollozzo now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kid's right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about McCluskey?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's say now that we have to kill McCluskey.  We'll clear that up through our Newspaper contacts later.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on Mike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They want me to go to the conference with Sollozzo.  Set up the meeting for two days from now.  Sonny, get our informers to find out where the meeting will be held. Insist it has to be a public place: a bar or restaurant at the height of the dinner hour.  So I'll feel safe.  They'll check me when I meet them so I won't be able to carry a weapon; but Clemenza, figure out a way to have one planted there for me. (pause) Then I'll kill them both. Everyone in the room is astonished; they all look at MICHAEL. Silence.  SONNY suddenly breaks out in laughter.  He points a finger at MICHAEL, trying to speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You?  You, the high-class college kid.  You never wanted to get mixed up in the family business.  Now you wanta gun down a police Captain and the Turk just because you got slapped in the face.  You're taking it personal, it's just business and he's taking it personal. Now CLEMENZA and TESSIO are also smiling; only HAGEN keeps his face serious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sonny, it's all personal, and I learned it from him, the old man, the Godfather.  He took my joining the Marines personal.  I take Sollozzo trying to kill my father personal, and you know I'll kill them Sonny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: radiates danger...SONNY stops laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : CLEMENZA'S CELLAR (WINTER 1945) CLOSE on a revolver.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's as cold as they come, impossible to trace. (he turns it upside down) Don't worry about prints Mike, I put a special tape on the trigger and butt.  Here. (he hands the gun to another pair of hands) Whatsamatter?  Trigger too tight. (it fires: very LOUD) I left it noisy, so it'll scare any pain-in-the-neck innocent bystander away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is alone with CLEMENZA in a cellar workshop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just let your hand drop to your side, and let the gun slip out. Everybody will still think you got it.  They'll be starin' at your face, see?  Then walk out of the place real fast, but don't run. Don't look anybody directly in the eye, but don't look away from them neither.  Hey, they'll be scared stiff o you, believe me.  Nobody's gonna bother with you.  Don't worry about nothing; you'd be surprised how good these things go.  O.K., put your hat on, let's see how you look.  Helps with identification. They put the hat on; CLEMENZA adjusts it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mostly it gives witnesses an excuse to change their identification when we make them see the light.  Then you take a long vacation and we catch the hell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How bad will it be?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Probably all the other families will line up against us.  But, it's alright.  These things have to happen once every ten years or so...gets rid of the bad blood. You gotta stop 'em at the beginning. Like they shoulda stopped Hitler at Munich, they shoulda never let him get away with that, they were just asking for big trouble...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S HALL & LIVING ROOM (WINTER 1945) MICHAEL steps into the foyer of the main house.  A card table is set up with a man playing cards with three of the Corleone buttonmen. He continues into the living room.  It's a mess.  SONNY asleep on the sofa.  On the coffee table are the remains of a take-out Chinese food dinner, and a half-empty bottle of whisky.  The radio is playing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you stop living like a bum and get this place cleaned up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you, inspecting the barracks? (SONNY sits up with his head in his hands) You ready?  Did Clemenza tell you be sure to drop the gun right away?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A million times.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sollozzo and McCluskey are going to pick you up in an hour and a half on Times Square, under the big Camels sign.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We don't let Mike go until we have the hostage, Sonny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's okay...the hostage is outside playing pinochle with three of my men. The phone rings in the DON's office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That could be a Tattaglia informer with the meeting place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S OFFICE (WINTER 1945) HAGEN has hurried into the Den to get the phone; the OTHERS move in. HAGEN's on the phone; he writes something down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One of Tattaglia's people?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  Our informer in McCluskey's precinct.  Tonight at 8:00 he signed out for Louis' Restaurant in the Bronx.  Anyone know it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, I do.  It's perfect for us. A small family place with big booths where people can talk in private.  Good food.  Everybody minds their business.  Perfect. (he moves to the desk and makes a crude drawing) This is the entrance, Mike.  When you finish just walk out and turn left, then turn the corner. Clemenza, you gotta work fast to plant the gun.  They got an old- fashioned toilet with a space between the water container and the wall.  We can tape the gun behind there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mike, they're gonna frisk you in the car.  You'll be clean so they won't worry 'bout nothing.  In the restaurant, wait and talk a while, and then ask permission to go.  See? Then when you come out, don't waste time; don't sit down...you come out blasting.  And don't take chances. In the head, two shots apiece.  And out as fast as your legs can move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want somebody very good, very safe to plant that gun.  I don't want my brother coming out of that toilet with just his dick in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The gun will be there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're on, kid...I'll square it with Mom your not seeing her before you left.  And I'll get a message to your girl friend when I think the time is right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We gotta move...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .K.  How long do you think before I can come back?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Probably a year...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus, I don't know...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you do it Mike?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: moves out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : CAMELS SIGN (WINTER 1945) The enormous "CAMELS" sign, puffing smoke, below it stands
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: dressed in a warm overcoat, and wearing the hat
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: had given him.  A long black car pulls around the corner and slows before him.  The DRIVER, leaning over, open the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get in, Mike. He does, the car drives off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : SOLLOZZO'S CAR (WINTER 1945) Inside the car, SOLLOZZO reaches his hand over the back seat and shakes MIKE's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm glad you came, Mike.  I hope we can straighten everything out.  All this is terrible, it's not the way I wanted things to happen at all. It should never have happened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to settle things tonight.  I want my father left alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He won't be; I swear to you be my children he won't be.  Just keep an open mind when we talk.  I hope you're not a hothead like your brother, Sonny.  It's impossible to talk business with him. McCLUSKEY grunts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a good kid.  He's all right. Turn around, up on your knees, facing me. He gives MICHAEL a thorough frisk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry about the other night Mike.  I'm getting too old for my job, too grouchy.  Can't stand the aggravation.  You know how it is. He's clean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : SOLLOZZO'S CAR - WEST SIDE HIGHWAY (WINTER 1945) MICHAEL looks at the DRIVER and then ahead to see where they're heading. The car takes the George Washington Bridge.  MICHAEL is concerned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're going to New Jersey?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: closes his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : SOLLOZZO'S CAR ON G.W. BRIDGE (WINTER 1945) The car speeds along the George Washington Bridge on its way to New Jersey.  Then suddenly it hits the divider, temporarily lifts into the air, and bounces over into the lanes going back to New York.  It then hits it very fast, on the way back to the city.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : SOLLOZZO'S CAR (WINTER 1945) SOLLOZZO checks to see the cars that had been following, and then leans to the DRIVER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice work; I'll remember it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is relieved.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : LUNA AZURA RESTAURANT (WINTER 1945) The car pulls up in front of a little family restaurant in the Bronx:  The "LUNA AZURA".  There is no one on the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks to see if the DRIVER is going to get out with them.  He gets out, and opens the door.  SOLLOZZO, McCLUSKEY and MICHAEL get out; the DRIVER remains leaning against the car.  They enter the restaurant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : LUNA AZURA (WINTER 1945) A very small family restaurant with a mosaic tile floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and McCLUSKEY sit around a rather small round table near the center of the room.  There are empty booths along the side walls; with a handful of CUSTOMERS, and ONE or TWO WAITERS.  It is very quiet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is the Italian food good here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Try the veal; it's the finest in New York. The solitary WAITER brings a bottle of wine to the table. They watch him silently as he uncorks it and pours three glasses.  Then, when he leaves, SOLLOZZO turns to McCLUSKEY:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am going to talk Italian to Mike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, you two go right ahead; I'll concentrate on my veal and my spaghetti.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: now begins in rapid Sicilian.  MICHAEL listening carefully and nodding every so often.  Then MICHAEL answers in Sicilian, and SOLLOZZO goes on.  The WAITER occasionally brings food; and they hesitate while he is there; then go on. Then MICHAEL, having difficulty expressing himself in Italian, accidentally lapses into English.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Most important...I want a sure guarantee that no more attempts will be made on my father's life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What guarantees can I give you?  I am the hunted one.  I've missed my chance.  You think too highly of me, my friend...I am not so clever...all I want if a truce...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks long and hard at SOLLOZZO, who is smiling holding his open hands up as if to say: "I have no tricks up my sleeve".  Then he looks away and makes a distressed look on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is it all right if I go to the bathroom?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is intuitively suspicious.  He studies MICHAEL with his dark eyes.  Then he thrusts his hand onto MICHAEL's thigh feeling in and around, searching for a weapon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I frisked him; I've frisked thousands of young punks; he's clean. He looks at a MAN sitting at a table opposite them; indicating the bathroom with his eyes.  The MAN nods, indicating no one is there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't take too long.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: gets up and calmly walks to the bathroom, and disappears inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : LUNA AZURA TOILET (WINTER 1945) MICHAEL steps into the small bathroom; he is breathing very hard.  He actually uses the urinal.  Then he washes his hands with the bar of pink soap; and dries them thoroughly. Then he moves to the booth, up to the old-fashioned toilet. Slowly he reaches behind the water tank; he panics when he cannot feel the gun.  We see behind the tank his hand is just a few inches from the gun...he gropes searchingly...finally coming to rest on the gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ; the feel of it reassures him.  Then he breaks it loose from the tape holding it; he takes a deep breath and shoves it under his waistband.  For some unexplainable reason he hesitates once again, deliberately washes his hands and dries them.  Then he goes out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : LUNA AZURA (WINTER 1945) He hesitates by the bathroom door; and looks at his table. McCLUSKEY is eating a plate of spaghetti and veal.  SOLLOZZO turns around upon hearing the door, and looks directly at
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .  MICHAEL looks back.  Then he smiles and continues back to the table.  He sits down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now I can talk.  I feel much better. The MAN by the far wall had been stiff with attention; now he too relaxes.  SOLLOZZO leans toward MICHAEL who sits down comfortably and his hands move under the table and unbutton his jacket.  SOLLOZZO begins to speak in Sicilian once again but MICHAEL's heart is pounding so hard he can barely hear him. The WAITER comes to ask about the order, SOLLOZZO turns to speak, and without warning, MICHAEL shoves the table away from him with his left hand, and with his right hand puts the gun right against SOLLOZZO's head, just touching his temple.  He pulls the trigger, and we see part of SOLLOZZO's head blown away, and a spray of fine mist of blood cover the entire area. The WAITER looks in amazement; suddenly his white jacket is sprayed and stained with blood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: seems in a perpetual fall to the floor; through he seems to hang in space suspended.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pivots, and looks: There is McCLUSKEY, frozen, the fork with a piece of veal suspended in air before his gaping mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: fires; catching McCLUSKEY in his thick bulging throat.  He makes a horrible, gagging, choking sound.  Then coolly, and deliberately, MICHAEL fires again, fires right through McCLUSKEY's white-topped skull. The air is filled with pink mist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: swings toward the MAN standing by the bathroom wall. He does not make a move, seemingly paralyzed. Now he carefully shows his hands to be empty. The WAITER steps backward through the mist of blood, an expression of horror on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks at his two victims:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: still in his chair, side of his body propped up by the table. McCLUSKEY finally falls from the chair to the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is wildly at a peak.  He starts to move out.  His hand: is frozen by his side, STILL GRIPPING THE GUN. He moves, not letting the gun go. MICHAEL's face; frozen in its expression. His hand: still holding the gun. His face: finally he closes his eyes. His hand relaxes, the gun falls to the floor with a dull thud. He walks quickly out of the restaurant, looks back. He sees a frozen tableau of the murder; as though it had been recreated in wax. Then he leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MATTRESS (WINTER 1945) A MAN is his shirtsleeves plays a sentimental tune on an old upright piano, while his cigarette burns on the edge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stands nearby, listening quietly. A little distance away, TEN MEN sit around a crude table, quietly eating.  They talk in low, relaxed voices, and there is an occasional laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stands by a window, which has been covered with a heavy-mesh wire grating, gazing out. A large bowl of pasta is passed, and the MEN eat heartily. The sentimental tune is continued over the following:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : BODIES IN CAR (WINTER 1945) A MAN and a WOMAN, blood coming out of their noses, lie still together in a bullet-riddled automobile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : BODY IN BARBER SHOP (WINTER 1945) A MAN is covered by a sheet on the floor of a barber shop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MATTRESS Ten mattresses are spread out around the otherwise empty living room of an apartment.  THREE or FOUR MEN including
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: are taking naps. An arsenal of hand guns are spread out on a card table. The MEN at the table continue their dinner; passing and pouring the wine. Trash is thrown in 2 or 3 garbage cans kept in the apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : BODY IN OFFICE (WINTER 1945) A MAN, his clothes soaked in blood, lies on the floor of an office building, dead, under an enormous portrait of Harry S. Truman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : BODY ON STOOP (WINTER 1945) ANOTHER MAN, his trousers soaked in blood, lies spanning three steps of a front stoop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MATTRESS (WINTER 1945) TESSIO, sits in a simple straight-backed chair, doing a crossword puzzle. A thin, boyish BUTTON MAN, writes a letter. Six or seven empty mattresses, with tossed unmade blankets. Coffee cans beside them serve as ash trays.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: by the table pulls the cork on another bottle of Ruffino, and wine is poured as the MEN eat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : BODY IN ALLEY (WINTER 1945) A CORPSE is half out of an overturned garbage can in a quiet alley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : BODY AT TABLE (WINTER 1945) A MAN in a formal jacket and tie is slumped over a table, in a pool of blood on the tablecloth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MATTRESS (WINTER 1945) A neatly stacked pile of newspapers in the corner of an apartment.  We catch a glimpse of one headline: "Five Family War..." The table.  The MEN are sitting around cracking nuts.  ONE has fallen asleep on his arms at the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: are taking naps on the Mattresses. The PIANO PLAYER finishes the tune with finesse.  Picks up and takes a drag from his cigarette.  The OTHER MAN nods appreciatively.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice Augie...nice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MANCINI BLDG. (SPRING '46) Several cars are parked in front of a pleasant New York apartment building.  We recognize a couple of SONNY's bodyguards loafing by the cars, pitching playing cards against the curb. Inside the building, two others wait quietly by the rows of brass mailboxes: they have been there quite awhile. Up one flight of stairs, a single man sits on the step, smoking a cigarette. One of the men by the mailboxes checks his pocketwatch, which is attached to a key chain.  We HEAR the sound of a door opening; they look up. The man sitting on the stop stands; and looks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: backs out of an apartment, the arms of LUCY MANCINI wrapped around him.  She doesn't want to let go of him; she draws him back into the apartment for a moment, and then he comes out alone, adjusting his clothes. He jauntily skips down the steps, trailed by the bodyguard on the first floor, and moves outside toward his car.  The men quickly take up their positions.  As he gets in his car:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pick up your sister?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. The car drives off; accompanied and escorted by the bodyguards in their cars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : CONNIE'S HALL (SPRING '46) He knocks on the door.  No answer.  Then again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's me, Sonny. We hear the bolt slide back, and see the door open.  SONNY enters, but CONNIE has quickly moved into the hallway, her back to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Connie, what is it? He turns her around in his arms. Her face is swollen and bruised; and we can tell from her rough, red eyes that she has been crying for a long time. As soon as he realizes what's happened, his face goes red with rage.  She sees it coming, and clings to him, preventing him from running out of the apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was my fault!  I started a fight with him and I tried to hit him so he hit me.  He didn't even try to hit me hard Sonny, I walked into it. Sonny listens, and calms himself.  He touches her shoulder, the thin silk robe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm goin' to have the doctor come over and take a look at you. He starts to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh Sonny, please don't do anything. Please don't. He stops, and then laughs good naturedly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey.  Con.  What'm I goin' to do? Make your kid a orphan before he's born. She laughs with him.  He kisses her reassuringly, and leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : CONNIE'S STREET CARLO settles down on the front steps of the 112th St. "Book" with SALLY RAGS and COACH, who have been drinking beer out of glasses and a pitcher of beer from around the corner.  The ball game is blaring from the radio; and the kids on the street are still playing stickball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: has barely settled down, when the kids in the street suddenly scatter, and a car comes screeching up the block and to a halt in front of the candy store.  The tires scream, and before it seems as though it has even stopped, a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: comes hurtling out of the driver's seat, moving so fast the everyone is paralyzed.  It is a moment before we recognize that it is SONNY. His face is contorted with anger; in a split second he is on the stoop and has CARLO by the throat. He pulls CARLO away from the others, trying to get him down into the street.  But CARLO reaches out for the iron railing, and hangs on, his hand in a lock, cringing away, trying to hide his head and face in the hollow of the his shoulders. His shirt is ripped away in SONNY's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and COACH, merely sit, watching, stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is pounding the cowered CARLO with all his strength, in a continuous monologue of indistinguishable cursing.  His blows are powerful; and begin to draw blood. The kids who have been playing stickball, move up, watching in fascination. CARLO's hands are clenched tight around the railing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: beats him mercilessly. Now SONNY's bodyguards' car pulls up, and they too become spectators. SONNY's tight fists are going down like hammers, into CARLO's face and body. CARLO's nose is bleeding profusely; but still he does nothing, other than hang onto the railing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: grabs hold of CARLO's massive body, and tries to drag him off of the hold on the railing, his teeth clenched in the effort.  Then he tries loosening CARLO's locked hands; even biting them.  CARLO screams but he does not let go. It's clear that CARLO is much stronger than he is, and will not be moved.  SONNY knees him in the mouth, and beats him more; but he is exhausted.  Totally out of breath, he stammers haltingly to the bleeding CARLO.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You...bastard...You...hurt my sister... again...and I'll kill...you. He wipes the sweat from his face, and then turns suddenly. and hurries back to the car, in a moment his car is gone, leaving even his bodyguards in confusion.  We notice ONE MAN with a sports jacket in the group of spectators especially interested.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: finally relaxes the clenched, locked hands.  He slumps onto the stoop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MALL (SPRING 1946) HIGH ANGLE on the Corleone Mall.  It is a gray, rainy day. Young BUTTON MEN in raincoats stand in quiet groups of various points around the main house and compound.  Things have changed; one house has been extensively enlarged; a new and secure gate house has been built.  Security measures that had been make-shift and temporarily have now been made a permanent part of the Mall, evolving it into a Medieval Fortress.  We notice a huge crater in the courtyard; the result of a recent bomb attempt.  The house nearest the crater is damaged by fire. A taxi arrives; KAY ADAMS steps out, huddled in a bright yellow raincoat; she lets the cab go, and hurries to the shelter of the gate house. They are not expecting her, and ask her to wait while they call the main house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks at the imposing, depressing Mall, while rain still runs down onto her face. She notices the bomb crater, and the fire damage; and the sullen faces of the BUTTON MEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: exits the Main House, and hurries toward her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kay, we weren't expecting you.  You should call...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've tried calling and writing.  I want to reach Michael.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody knows where he is.  We know he's all right, but that's all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks in the direction of the crater, filling with rainwater.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What was that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An accident.  No one was hurt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen Tom, I let my cab go; can I come in to call another one?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is clearly reluctant to involve her any more than he has to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure...I'm sorry. They hurry through the rain and into the Main House.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S LIVING ROOM (SPRING 1946) In the living room, KAY shakes the water from her coat and takes her rainhat off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you give this to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I accept that letter and you told a Court of Law I accepted it, they would interpret it as my having knowledge of his whereabouts. Just wait Kay, he'll contact you. We hear footsteps descending the staircase; MAMA CORLEONE enters the room; the OLD WOMAN squints at KAY, evaluating her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're Mikey's little girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: nods yes; there are still tears in her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You eat anything?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Disgrazia, you don't even give the poor girl a cup of coffee?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: shrugs helplessly; on an impulse, KAY quickly moves toward MAMA, the letter extended.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you give this letter to Michael.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mama, no.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You tell me what to do?  Even he don't tell me what to do. She takes the letter from KAY, who is grateful and relieved.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why did they blame Michael?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You listen to me, you go home to your family, and you find a good young man and get married.  Forget about Mikey; he's no good for you, anymore. She looks directly into KAY's eyes; and KAY understands what that means.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S HOSPITAL (SPRING 1946) A hospital in New York City.  POLICE and teams of PRIVATE DETECTIVES are stationed guarding the area.  An ambulance with a team of DETECTIVES and BUTTON-MEN GUARDS exit the hospital with rifles in hand; followed by SEVERAL HOSPITAL ASSISTANTS wheeling a hospital stretcher, presumably carrying the DON.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and CLEMENZA emerge, with OTHER BUTTON MEN bringing up the rear.  HAGEN walks with the stretcher, and for a moment they disappear behind the ambulance.  Then suddenly, siren blasting, it speeds off, accompanied by dark low-slung cars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MALL (SPRING 1946) The Corleone Mall. Equally impressive security stands ready at the Corleone Mall.  EXTRA BUTTON MEN, as well as SOME POLICE, and PRIVATE DETECTIVES. It all seems to be under the supervision of ROCCO LAMPONE. All is silent.  The WOMEN and CHILDREN, dressed in Sunday clothes, wait.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : AMBULANCE (SPRING 1946) One ambulance, speeding along the Grand Central Parkway, preceded and followed by a dark car, each one carrying a team of BUTTON MEN. Sitting next to the DRIVER of the ambulance is a GUARD with a rifle on his lap.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: MAMA, FREDO, SANDRA, THERESA, CONNIE, CARLO

direction.raw_text: : DON'S HALL (SPRING 1946) Inside the Main CORLEONE House: Hospital ORDERLIES carry the DON on his stretcher carefully under the watchful eyes of CLEMENZA, TESSIO, LAMPONE and various GUARDS and BUTTON MEN. All the CORLEONE family is here today: MAMA, FREDO, SANDRA, THERESA, CONNIE, CARLO; the various CORLEONE CHILDREN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S BEDROOM (SPRING 1946) The DON is made comfortable in his room, which has all but been converted into a hospital room, with complete and extensive equipment.  The various CHILDREN get a turn to kiss the OLD MAN, as he is made comfortable... and then
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: indicates that all the CHILDREN, WOMEN, and CARLO should leave. They do, the door is closed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S DINING ROOM (SPRING 1946) The mood is quite happy downstairs, as the WOMEN prepare the Sunday dinner, and set the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: sits alone among them, a frown on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the matter, Carlo?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shut up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S BEDROOM (SPRING 1946) All the MEN of the family stand around the hospital bed with grim faces, SONNY and HAGEN closest to the OLD MAN.  The DON does not speak, yet he asks questions with his looks and glances, as clearly as if they were verbalized.  HAGEN is the spokesman for the family.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...since McCluskey's killing, the police have cracked down on most of our operations...on the other families too.  There's been a lot of bad blood. The OLD MAN glances at SONNY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pop, they hit us and we hit them back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We put out a lot of material through our contacts in the Newspapers...about McCluskey's being tied up with Sollozzo in the Drug Rackets...things are starting to loosen up. The OLD MAN nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Freddie's gonna go to Las Vegas...under the protection of Don Francesco of L.A.  I want him to rest...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm goin' to learn the casino business. The DON nods approvingly.  Then he searches around the room for a face he does not see.  HAGEN knows who he's looking for.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Michael... (he takes a breath) It was Michael who killed Sollozzo. The DON closes his eyes, and then reopens them in anger and rage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's safe now...we're already working on ways to bring him back. The DON is very angry, he motions with a weak hand that they leave him alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY: DON'S STAIRS AND HALL (SPRING 1946) HAGEN is very upset as he comes down the Stairs; SONNY is expansive and optimistic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll let the old man take it easy for a couple of weeks.  I want to get things going good before he gets better.  What's the matter with you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You start operating, the five families will start their raids again.  We're at a stalemate Sonny, your war is costing us a lot of money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No more stalemate Tom, we got the soldiers, we'll match them gun for gun if that's how they want it. They know me for what I am, Tom-- and they're scared of me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.  That's true, you're getting a hell of a reputation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well it's war!  We might not be in this shape if we had a real war- time Consiglere, a Sicilian.  Pop had Genco, who do I have? (TOM starts to leave) Hey Tom, hey...hey.  It's Sunday, we're gonna have dinner.  Don't be sore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S DINING ROOM (SPRING 1946) The FAMILY, WIVES, CHILDREN and all sit around the table over Sunday dinner.  SONNY is at the head of the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MALL (SPRING 1946) SOME of the CORLEONE GRANDCHILDREN play in the enclosed Mall, in the proximity of the BUTTON MEN stationed liberally by the gate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: misses a ball, it rolls by the gate house.  A young BUTTON MAN scoops it up and throws it back, smiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : CONNIE'S APT. (SPRING 1946)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and CARLO's apartment.  She's in a slip, on the phone. We HEAR the shower going in the bathroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a friend of Carlo's.  I just wanted to tell him I can't see him tonight; I have to go out of town. CONNIE's face turns red.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You lousy tramp bitch. (click) She slams the phone down; just as CARLO is coming out of the bathroom drying his golden body.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What was that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your girl friend.  She says she can't make it tonight.  You lousy bastard you have the nerve to give your whores my telephone number. I'll kill you, you bastard! She hauls off and punches him knowingly; he laughs, so then she flings herself at him, kicking and scratching; her heavy belly heaving under the thin slip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're crazy.  She was kidding around; I don't know, some nut. He pushes her aside, and moves into the bedroom to continue dressing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're staying home.  You're not going out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .  You gonna make me something to eat at least? That calms her down; she stands there a moment, breathing heavily; and then she nods, and goes into the kitchen, and starts her wifely duties.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is dressed; puts on some cologne; CONNIE appears in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The food is on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not hungry yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eat it, it's on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ba Fa Goulle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! She turns deliberately, goes out into the kitchen.  A moment later we begin to hear the sound of dishes breaking.  CARLO slowly walks out, where we can see CONNIE systematically smashing all the dishes against the sink, sending the greasy veal and peppers all over the apartment floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You filthy guinea spoiled brat. Clean it up or I'll kick your head in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like hell I will. She stands there, solid, ready to punch him again.  Slowly, he slides his belt out of his trousers, and doubles it in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clean it up! He swings the belt against her heavy hips.  She moves back into the kitchen, and gets a kitchen knife, and holds it ready.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Even the female Corleones are murderers. He puts the strap down on a table, and moves after her.  She makes a sudden thrust at his groin, which he avoids.  He pulls the knife away, cutting his hand in the process.  She gets away momentarily, but he pursues her around the table, gets her; and starts to slap her in the face. She breaks away from him, and rushes into the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The baby!  The baby!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : CONNIE'S BEDROOM  (SPRING 1946) She runs into the bedroom; he follows.  She moves into a corner, and then like a desperate animal, tries to hide under the bed. He reaches under, and pulls her out by the hair. He slaps her in the face until she begins to weep; then he throws her on the bed, contemptuously.  He grabs part of her thigh, pinching it very hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're fat as a pig. Then he pushes her away, and walks out of the room, leaving her in tears.  She is crying; she pulls herself to the bedroom phone, and in a whisper:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mama...mama, it's Connie.  Mama, I can't talk any louder.  No, I don't want to talk to Sonny. We can tell that the phone has been passed to SONNY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S KITCHEN (SPRING 1946) In the kitchen at the Mall, MAMA cannot understand the whispering and she has given the phone to SONNY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah Connie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sonny, just send a car to bring me home.  I'll tell you then, it's nothing Sonny, don't you come. Send TOM, please Sonny, it's nothing; I just want to come home. SONNY's face is turning red.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You wait there.  You just wait there. He hangs up the phone; and just stands there for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That sonofabitch; that sonofabitch...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: enters the room; he knows what is happening, knows he cannot interfere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MALL SONNY leaves the house.  HAGEN moves to the outside mall just as SONNY's car is driving off.  He moves to a group of
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : CAUSEWAY (SPRING 1946) SONNY's car on the Jones Beach Causeway, speeds quickly by. After a pause, another car, with the CORLEONE BODYGUARDS, is trailing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is driving; he is very angry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : TOLL BOOTHS (SPRING 1946) SONNY in his car; driving back.  Still breathing hard and still furious.  Then he thinks it's funny; he enjoyed it. He starts laughing, louder and louder, as he pulls up to a toll booth, stops, and extends his hand with a coin to the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : AMERIGO BONASERA'S APARTMENT The serious-faced UNDERTAKER is on the telephone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is Tom Hagen.  I'm calling for Don Corleone, at his request.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks at his WIFE, with deep anxiety in his eyes. BONASERA's lips are suddenly dry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I understand.  I'm listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You owe the Don a service.  In one hour, not before, perhaps later, he will be at your funeral parlor to ask for your help.  Be there to greet him.  If you have any objections speak now, and I'll inform him. Silence.  BONASERA stutters, then speaks in fright.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anything...Anything the Godfather wishes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good.  He never doubted you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Don himself is coming to me tonight?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. (click)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is sweating; slowly he lowers the phone; his WIFE sees his pale expression, and follows him into the room. Silently, he begins the ritual of dressing.  His WIFE knows something serious is happening, and never takes her eyes from him.  He lights a cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For the last year, they have been killing one another.  So now, what? Your Godfather comes to me...Why? (whispering, slyly) They've killed someone so important that they wish to make his body disappear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amerigo!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They could make me an accomplice to their murder.  They could send me to jail! He slips into his trousers.  Then he moves to his WIFE to tie his tie, as she has done for years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And if the other families find out...they will make me their enemy. They could come here to our house. I curse the day I ever went to the Godfather.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : FUNERAL PARLOR (SPRING 1946) With his ring of keys, he opens the funeral parlor, enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : FUNERAL PARLOR (SPRING 1946) BONASERA walks through the darkened funeral parlor, without turning on the lights; then into the rear, preparation room, past the tables, and equipment.  He operates the chain that lifts a large overhead garage type door.  And looks out into the alley. He sits on a bench, and waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : FUNERAL PARLOR ALLEY (SPRING 1946) The tires of a car roll very quietly along the small alley; we notice a dark car approach the rear of BONASERA's funeral parlor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: gets out, and moves to the open, rear door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: greets him, too petrified to speak.  He notices TWO OTHER MEN get out of the car, and carry a stretcher with a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: swaddled in a gray blanket, with yellowed feet protruding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: closes his eyes in fear, but indicates which way the MEN should carry their sinister burden.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : FUNERAL PARLOR EMBALMING ROOM (SPRING 1946) They carry the CORPSE to one of the tables in the embalming room. Then BONASERA turns to see ANOTHER MAN step out of the darkness somewhat uncertainly.  It is DON CORLEONE. He walks up to BONASERA, very close, without speaking.  His cold eyes looking directly at the frightened UNDERTAKER. Then, after a long gaze:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well my friend, are you ready to do me this service?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: nods.  The DON moves to the CORPSE on the embalming table; he makes a gesture, and the OTHER MEN leave them alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you wish me to do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want you to use all your powers, all your skill, as you love me.  I do not want his mother to see him as he is. He draws down the gray blanket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: lets out a gasp of horror at what he sees: The bullet-smashed face of SONNY CORLEONE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : TOLL BOOTHS (SPRING 1946) SONNY extends his hand with a coin at the toll booth. A car suddenly swerves in front of him, trapping him in the booth, and in incredible rally of machine gun fire greets him, coming through and smashing the windows of the toll booths on both side of him, and from the front window of the car blocking him. The windows of his car are shot out. Bullet holes puncture the doors of his car. His hand, with the coin in it, falls inside the car. His arms, shoulders are riddled by the fire, and still it continues, as though the ASSASSINS cannot take a chance that he will survive it. Suddenly, he lets out an enormous ROAR, like a bull, and actually, opens the door, and steps out of the car, UNDER fire. His face is hit; and finally he falls to the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...as the ASSASSINS scramble for their cars and make off in the distance. SONNY's BODYGUARDS stop a safe distance away, realizing they are too late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S LIVING ROOM (SPRING 1946) View on HAGEN's ashen face in the living room.  He is silent a moment, and then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .  Go to Clemenza's house and tell him to come here right away. He'll tell you what to do. The MEN leave him alone.  He is quiet, standing in the middle of the living room a moment.  He looks in the direction of the kitchen, where he can see fragments of MAMA moving around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : UPSTAIRS (SPRING 1946) TOM proceeds up stairs, and quietly in the direction of the DON's room.  He opens the DON's door.  Looks in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S BEDROOM (SPRING 1946) The DON in his hospital bed.  Asleep under sedation.  HAGEN hesitates.  He cannot go in; he cannot tell the OLD MAN.  He closes the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : DON'S OFFICE (SPRING 1946) HAGEN alone in the office.  He is drinking.  He looks up at the sound of cars; the CAPOREGIMES are arriving.  Then he hears footsteps. The door opens; and in a robe, with slippers, DON CORLEONE slowly enters the room.  He walks directly to his stuffed armchair, sits down.  His face is stern, as he looks into HAGEN's eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give me a drop of anisette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: rises, and pours a glass for the OLD MAN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My wife was weeping before she fell asleep, outside my window I saw my caporegimes to the house, and it is midnight.  So, Consigliere of mine, I think you should tell your Don what everyone knows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't tell Mama anything.  I was about to come up and wake you and tell you.  Just now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you needed a drink first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now you've had your drink. Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They shot Sonny on the Causeway. (pause) He's dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: blinks.  One feels that just for a second he loses all physical strength; he clasps his hands in front of him on the top of the desk and looks into HAGEN's eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want no inquiries made.  No acts of vengeance. (pause) Consigliere, arrange a meeting with the heads of the five families...this war stops now. He rises and unsteadily leaves the room, turns...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Call Bonasera...he will do me a service. And leaves.  HAGEN moves to the phone; dials...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is Tom Hagen; I'm calling for Don Corleone, at his request.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I understand I'm listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You owe the Don a service.  He has no doubt that you will repay it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : BANK BUILDING (SPRING 1946) Day in Manhattan.  An impressive Bank Building in the financial center of New York.  Many limousines are parked, uniforms and plain-clothed CHAUFFEURS waiting quietly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : BOARD ROOM (SPRING 1946) The Board Room of a bank, daylight shines in the windows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: an impressive, handsome middle-aged man, sits quietly, smoking a Di Napoli cigar, OUR VIEW moves to a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: sitting to his left, and a little to the rear, and settles on JOSEPH ZALUCHI, a moon-faced amiable-looking man; as the view continues, around the table, we HEAR:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to thank you all for coming. I consider it a service done to me personally and I am in the debt of each and every one of you. Especially those of you who have traveled from such distances as California, St. Louis, Kansas City; and New Orleans... The VIEW PASSES to FRANK FALCONE and ANTHONY MOLINARI, both younger than any of the others; then on to DOMENICK PANZA, short and squat sitting in a wheelchair; then around the table to DON VINCENENZO FORLENZA, who is whispering to his
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ; the VIEW PASSES on to ANTHONY STRACCI, an older man, sipping from a drink and smoking a cigar; OTTILIO CUNEO, in his middle sixties with a jolly round face; then
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a delicate older man with dyed hair and a pencil mustache; and finally, EMILIO BARZINI, in his early sixties, a man to 'respect'; whom we had seen at CONNIE's Wedding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah well, let's get down to business. We are all honorable men here, we don't have to give assurances as if we were lawyers. (he sits, gazes out at them, and sighs) How did things ever go so far? Well, no matter.  A lot of foolishness has come to pass.  It was so unfortunate, so unnecessary. The VIEW examines the room once again, as the DON speaks.  A large, clicking board is changing numbers at various times, and two tapes, showing the fluctuations of the Market during the day's trading, and projected above.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pauses; and TOM HAGEN hands him a cold drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tattaglia has lost a son; I have lost a son.  We are quits.  Let there be a peace... (he gestures expressively, submissively, with his hands) That is all I want...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don Corleone is too modest.  He had the judges and politicians in his pocket and he refused to share them. His refusal is not the act of a friend.  He takes the bread out of the mouths of our families.  Times have changed, it's not like the old days where everyone can go his own way.  If Don Corleone had all the judges and politicians in New York, then he must share them or let others use them.  Certainly he can present a bill for such services, we're not Communists, after all. But he has to let us draw water from the well.  It's that simple.
direction.name: direction
